Artpop is Lady Gaga's album that received mixed reviews but was commercially successful, debuting at number one in the U.S. with 258,000 copies sold in the first week. It became her second consecutive U.S. number-one record and sold 757,000 copies overall. The album was the ninth best seller of 2013, with 2.3 million copies sold worldwide.
John Frusciante's fifth and final album with the Chili Peppers, Stadium Arcadium, was released in 2006. This album was also the last to feature guitarist John Frusciante, who left the band in 2009.

Margaret Thatcher, as Prime Minister, implemented policies termed Thatcherism. She remains a controversial figure, praised as one of Britain's greatest and most influential politicians, despite ongoing debates over Thatcherism.

Michael Andrew "Duff" McKagan is an American musician, singer, songwriter, and author. He has also made a name for himself as a writer, contributing weekly columns to SeattleWeekly.com, Playboy.com, and ESPN.com.
Tom Baker, an English actor, has also worked as a narrator for commercials, video games, audiobooks, and television series.

Valencia, officially València, is the capital of the autonomous community of Valencia in Spain. It is the country's third largest city after Madrid and Barcelona, with around 800,000 inhabitants in its administrative center. Valencia is also the third largest metropolitan area in Spain, with a population ranging from 1.7 to 2.5 million. The Valencian Community, or the Valencian Country, is an autonomous community of Spain, with Valencia as its homonymous capital city and metropolitan area.
Buffy Summers was played by Kristy Swanson in a film and later by Sarah Michelle Gellar in the television series.
The series "Make It or Break It" concluded after three seasons, with the final season announced on April 26, 2012. The series finale aired on May 14, 2012.

Speech recognition is a sub-field of computational linguistics that enables computers to recognize and translate spoken language into text. It combines knowledge from linguistics, computer science, and electrical engineering. Applications include voice user interfaces, call routing, home automation, search, data entry, document preparation, speech-to-text processing, and aircraft systems. The field has seen significant advancements due to the adoption of deep learning methods by major industry players like Google, Microsoft, IBM, and others.
Richard Alf, an American businessman and former comic book store owner, co-founded the San Diego Comic-Con International in 1970. He also served as its chairman.
Fist of Legend is a remake of the 1972 film Fist of Fury, starring Bruce Lee as the main character.

Rory McIlroy, tied with Van Zyl of South Africa and Kiradech Aphibarnrat of Thailand, carded a third consecutive five under-par 67. Despite a three-putt on the third and 10th holes, he made a birdie on the 11th and an eagle on the 13th. McIlroy aims for his first title since May and is targeting a third Race to Dubai title in four years. He leads England's Danny Willett by 271 points with three events remaining.

Sheikh Ali Salman emphasized the necessity of the government's willingness to provide concrete solutions for meaningful national dialogue. Crown Prince Salman al-Khalifa, viewed as a reformist, is seen as a potential partner for dialogue with opposition groups. However, hardliners within the government, led by unelected Prime Minister Sheikh Khalifa bin Salman al-Khalifa, oppose dialogue, fearing it will encourage further demands from distrusted opposition leaders. Despite this, Sheikh Salman insists on dialogue and negotiations, expressing hope for US Secretary of State John Kerry to push for clearer human rights policies. He also criticizes the UK for not publicly pressuring Bahrain to end violence and human rights abuses. Al-Wefaq leader reiterates the call for peaceful demonstrations and the release of imprisoned opposition leaders, stating their involvement is crucial for successful dialogue.

Christopher Hogwood, a renowned figure in the early-music movement, passed away at his Cambridge home after a prolonged illness. He was the founder of the Academy of Ancient Music (AAM) and directed it for three decades, producing over 200 CDs. Hogwood's influential recordings include the 1980 Handel's Messiah. He studied at Cambridge University and held various prestigious positions, including artistic director of the King's Lynn Festival and Boston's Handel and Haydn Society. He was also a tutor at Harvard University and honorary professor at the University of Cambridge and Cornell University. His death is mourned by many, with his legacy in historically informed music being highly regarded.

The number of homicide victims in Scotland decreased to 57 for the year ending March 2016, the lowest in a decade. One case from the previous year remained unsolved. Despite this decline, sexual crimes are at a 45-year high, and violent crimes like attempted murder and serious assault increased by 27%. Sharp instruments, mainly knives, were used in 51% of homicides. Efforts to reduce violent crime continue, with a focus on education, enforcement, and addressing irresponsible attitudes towards alcohol misuse and violence.

The Cherries lost 2-1 to Sunderland in the Premier League, marking the first loss for Sunderland against Bournemouth this season. Despite having six goals against Hull before these games, Bournemouth failed to score due to missed opportunities and a lack of confidence. Sunderland's victory was aided by goals from Victor Anichebe and Jermain Defoe, with Bournemouth unable to equalize even with a man down after Steven Pienaar's dismissal.

Mr Abbott, the Australian leader, asserts that halting boats is the only way to prevent deaths at sea. Australia detains migrants at sea and resettles them offshore, a policy the New York Times labels "brutal" and "inhumane". Despite criticism, Abbott defends his stance, comparing IS militants' boasting of their evil to the Nazis' shame. Australian Jewish groups condemn Abbott's comments, stating a significant difference between IS terrorism and Nazi genocide.

Washington blamed Russia and the Syrian government for intensifying attacks against civilians in Aleppo, Syria. The US suspended talks and bilateral channels with Russia due to Russia's alleged failure to prevent bombings and ensure adherence to agreements. Russia denied involvement in a deadly aid convoy strike and criticized the US for not fulfilling key conditions of the agreement and for failing to separate jihadist groups from the moderate opposition.

Downing Street supports a Policy Exchange report suggesting selling high-value vacant homes could raise £4.5bn annually. This funding could build 80,000-170,000 social homes, potentially reducing the 1.8 million on waiting lists by half a million. Critics, including Labour, argue this policy would displace low-income families and exacerbate segregation. Policy Exchange defines expensive social housing as worth more than the average property in each region, which accounts for 21.8% of the total social housing stock in the UK.

Gareth Colfer-Williams, 25, died in Swansea amidst a measles epidemic, with 942 cases reported. Despite laboratory confirmation of measles, the cause of death remains undetermined. An inquest is set for Tuesday to conduct further tests. Mr. Colfer-Williams had been treated for asthma and developed a rash before his death. His family was unaware of how he contracted measles, as no close relatives had the disease, and his daughter was vaccinated.
Vincent Hudson, 54, charged with a 2001 historical offence involving a boy under 16 in Cumbria. He is set to appear in court later.

Neil Aspin's team, Guiseley, and Adam Lockwood's team, Gateshead, ended the match in a draw, with both teams scoring once. The game saw several key events, including Guiseley taking an early lead, Gateshead's defender blocking a shot, and both teams making substitutions. The match concluded with Guiseley and Gateshead each having one goal.

Bristol Sport Ltd, the owner of a football club, plans to replace two stands to increase stadium capacity. This plan is an alternative to building a new stadium at Ashton Vale, which has been delayed due to an application for a town green. The club's majority shareholder, Steve Lansdown, confirmed the club would start work after signing a section 106 agreement, with the project potentially beginning in May if no judicial review occurs.

Cuadrilla halted fracking operations in Lancashire, UK after a 1.5 magnitude tremor, the second in two months. The British Geological Survey (BGS) is analyzing data to determine if operations should resume. Fracking, or "hydraulic fracturing," involves releasing gas by fracturing shale rocks underground. Cuadrilla's CEO emphasized their commitment to safety and consultation with authorities. The BGS stated that any process injecting pressurized water into rocks could cause earthquakes, and they are monitoring fracking as a precaution. Two small earthquakes have occurred since fracking began in March. The latest tremor was felt in Poulton-le-Fylde and had a similar location and mechanism to a previous event.

Angus Carpenter, a Liverpool busker, denied three counts of fraud but was found guilty of one count related to a Hillsborough Justice Campaign banner he displayed while busking in 2015. He was cleared of two other counts and had permission from the charity's chairman to use the banner as a tribute, not for fundraising. Carpenter, known for his performances in the city centre, will be sentenced in January.

In the match, Ipswich Town secured a 3-0 victory over Queens Park Rangers. Grant Ward's shot was saved by Alex Smithies, but Luke Varney later rolled the ball into an empty net after a miscue by Smithies. Tom Lawrence scored the final goal for Ipswich, capitalizing on a long-range shot by Cole Skuse. Despite Ipswich's struggles in attack, they managed to overcome Rangers' defensive efforts. Rangers' keeper Smithies had a challenging game, with several costly errors, including misjudging a clearance and conceding a goal. Ipswich's manager, Mick McCarthy, acknowledged the team's lack of confidence but praised their performance in securing the win.

Wells, 23, performed impressively in the T20 Blast last season, scoring 373 runs with a strike rate of 138.66. He expressed excitement about the club's direction and the elite performance environment created by the coaches.

The Reds, currently fifth in National Two South, secured a second consecutive win against Chinnor with a score of 29-12. This victory was attributed to the efforts of players Tommy Phillips, Ben Priddey, and Craig Williams, who led the team with over 70 tackles. Despite the win, the coach, Churcher, emphasized the need for improvement and building on the previous week's performance, as the team faces seven upcoming matches against lower-ranked teams and league leaders Old Elthamians.

Nazrul, also known as Nazu, a 28-year-old Bangladeshi citizen, is alleged to be the man who raped a 74-year-old nun in India. He was arrested at a Kolkata railway station after police acted on a tip that he was returning to the city. This arrest is part of the investigation into a crime that has now resulted in six arrests, with eight suspects identified, two of whom remain untraced. The police claim that all five previously arrested individuals named Nazrul as the rapist. The incident also involved theft and ransacking of a convent school building.

The passage discusses an interactive video featuring Robert Opie, founder of the Museum of Brands, Packaging and Advertising in London. The video highlights factors influencing changes in UK consumer purchases, such as the introduction of domestic freezers, washing powder, and cheaper imports. It also examines shifts in ownership and ranking of major UK brands. A non-interactive version of the video is available for those using older browsers. Additional information can be found through provided links.

A woman in Stranraer lost money to a scammer pretending to be from BT technical support, who gained remote access to her computer. This incident occurred seven days after a similar scam in Sandyhills. Authorities warn people to be cautious of such cold calls and not to share banking details over the phone.

Duffy, a 37-year-old Scotland assistant coach, has signed a one-year contract with Featherstone to lead them in their final league game against Toulouse. He previously played for Leigh, Widnes, and Salford, and was replaced by his former assistant at Swinton. The Featherstone chairman praised Duffy's potential impact on the team.

A rider suffered head injuries and hypothermia after an incident at Sker Beach near Porthcawl. The RNLI crew, including a medic and coastguard, along with a rescue helicopter, attended the scene at 12:50 GMT on Sunday. The injured rider was then taken to Cardiff's University Hospital of Wales.

At a UN conference in Geneva, a decision was made to allocate a portion of the radio spectrum for a global flight tracking system. This initiative, proposed by more than 160 countries, aims to enhance the current system that relies on ground-based radars. The move was partly influenced by the 2014 disappearance of MH370, which highlighted the system's limitations, such as covering only 30% of the world's airspace. The new system will allow real-time tracking of aircraft worldwide, as stated by ITU's head. The UN's aviation body, ICAO, has set a deadline for adopting new tracking guidelines by November 2016.

Julian Hernandez, a 18-year-old boy, disappeared at age five and was found living with his father, Bobby Hernandez, in Cleveland. Bobby was arrested and charged with tampering with records in Ohio. The FBI, working with Alabama police, confirmed Julian's identity after issues with his college application. Julian's mother was informed of his recovery, and Bobby is currently detained at the Cuyahoga County Jail with a $250,000 bail.

Firefighters spent several days at a site in Duncan Street after a blaze on 2 March, which disrupted train services and caused travel delays. The Environment Agency suspended Recovered Fuels Shipping Limited from accepting waste due to the fire, despite the company being mostly compliant with fire safety laws. The firm, operated by Asset and Land Group, must appeal the decision by 7 August and remove all waste from the site. Concerns over potential impacts on residents, transport, and the environment led to joint visits by fire safety officers and the EA. The fire's cause is still unknown.

A Just Russia, a pro-Kremlin party, proposed two bills linked to the Ukraine crisis, particularly the strong separatist and pro-Russian sentiment in Ukraine's Crimea region. One bill suggests Russia could accept territories whose people wish to join Russia if a neighboring state disintegrates. The second bill aims to expedite Russian passport issuance for Ukrainians, with no state tax, no need for previous residence in Russia, or giving up Ukrainian citizenship. This is also seen as support for Russian-speaking Ukrainians amidst the 'brown threat'.

McLaren, a team with a history of 182 grand prix wins, 12 drivers' world championships, and eight constructors' titles, is currently experiencing a decline in performance. Despite having a car that is considered among the best, they are struggling with issues related to their Honda power unit. This decline began in 2013 and has led to their current position in the fourth row of the grid. However, team boss Dennis remains optimistic, believing that McLaren will break Mercedes' dominance and win the title again.

Tommy, aged 44 from Everton, was shot in the head and chest at Stanley Meat Market in Liverpool, dying in the hospital. Three men, aged 29 and 32, were arrested and remain in custody. Officers believe a silver VW polo left the scene and are searching for it. CCTV footage near the market has not yet been fully analyzed for potential leads.

The passage provides information on various ways to celebrate Christmas online and share spiritual messages. It mentions Everyday Church Online, which offers virtual services and recorded sermons in multiple languages, with the first Christmas theme being Star Wars. Another highlighted platform is Guardians of Ancora, a free-to-play fantasy game developed by the Scripture Union, aimed at children aged 8-11, which incorporates Bible stories into its gameplay. Additionally, the passage discusses the use of social media platforms like Facebook, Twitter, and Instagram for sharing Gospel messages and connecting with communities. It also touches on the use of Manga to convey biblical stories, with Next Manga launching its nativity story in app and e-book form in English.

The eight-day hearing in Ebbw Vale is assessing a request to develop 250 hectares of common land. Supporters, including Blaenau Gwent council, propose 800 acres of replacement land. Experts are divided on the potential environmental impact, with Natural Resources Wales unable to confirm the replacement land's equal value but not opposing the development. An ecology report suggests a "net gain" in biodiversity due to habitat enhancement nearby, a claim contested by the Gwent wildlife trust. The Planning Inspectorate for Wales will provide a recommendation before Welsh government ministers decide on the project's approval.

Chechen Muslim clerics, after a report by Novaya Gazeta, declared the publication insulted their faith and called for "retribution" against those responsible, including journalists. The report detailed the detention and torture of over 100 people in Chechnya, suspected of being homosexual. The Russian LGBT Network confirmed the report's accuracy, highlighting the region's homophobia. Novaya Gazeta's chief editor assured that their intent was not to insult the Chechen people and pledged to continue investigating human rights abuses. The Network also threatened to take the case to the International Criminal Court if Russia does not act against the abuses.

Investing Solutions and Fresh Start Housing, based in south London, have been involved in housing homeless men and passing rents to private landlords. The charity Fresh Start Housing sources clients from London homeless charities and refers them to both Investing Solutions and private landlords. Investing Solutions primarily receives housing benefit payments, which are higher than the rent paid to landlords. The company focuses on housing single homeless men over 35, despite housing benefit legislation allowing for private accommodation for this age group. Criticism has been raised regarding the quality of properties provided and the profitability of the venture. Wandsworth Council has paid Investing Solutions over £2.1 million in housing benefit over the past two years.

Andrew Lawrence and Ben Gordon, representing GB, scored a combined 27 points in a game where they initially led but were eventually overtaken by Netherlands in the last 10 minutes. Despite their efforts, GB lost to Netherlands, who won with a score of 71-60. The game was described as well-contested, and GB's coach, Joe Prunty, emphasized the importance of maintaining intensity throughout the game. Gordon, who joined GB after missing London 2012, had a notable performance, especially in the third quarter.

Former UFC champion Conor McGregor submitted a waiver to the Nevada Athletic Commission (NAC) to use lighter 8oz gloves for his boxing debut against Floyd Mayweather. This decision, which could result in more punishing punches, was met with criticism from boxing personalities. However, NAC executive director Bob Bennett, after studying information on McGregor and considering his UFC rival Nate Diaz's boxing skills, expressed several reasons to approve the fight. Despite some controversy, the NAC will publicly debate the matter before making a decision.

Reporters Gavin Sherriff and Darryl Smith, who worked for the Sunday Post, witnessed the closure of Fleet Street, a historic location in London known for its significant role in the nation's journalism. Fleet Street, synonymous with major newspapers, was once a hub for journalists, with offices of national and provincial papers within a half-mile radius. However, the rise of television and social media, along with the shift to computerized printing technology, led to the decline of Fleet Street's prominence. Media tycoon Rupert Murdoch's relocation of his papers in 1986 further contributed to the decline. The closure of Fleet Street marks the end of an era, with the last two journalists reflecting on the rich history and significance of the location.

J.K. Rowling, the author of Harry Potter, faced abusive comments on Twitter due to her political donations. She donated £1m to the Labour party in 2008 and to the No campaign in the Scottish independence referendum in 2014. Critics called her a traitor for her political views, leading her to block some abusive users. Despite the negativity, Rowling stood up to bullies and maintained her stance, even joking about bringing marshmallows if her books were to be burned. The SNP won 56 seats in the recent election, making them the third largest party in the UK.

The passage discusses a study by the University of Edinburgh, which found that children from deprived backgrounds are twice as likely to face police action for the same crime as better-off children. Poverty also increases the likelihood of violence among both genders. The study found that a history of police trouble predicts a young person's lack of education, employment, or training by age 18. Poorer young people are more likely to be placed on statutory supervision and are more likely to be victims and perpetrators of crime, even when other risk factors are considered. The study also found that areas with the most chronic rates of crime continue to experience high crime rates, and that these areas often have high levels of chronic health problems and unemployment. Despite overall crime rates in Scotland being at a 41-year low, the study suggests that crime is still highly concentrated among poor people and in poor neighborhoods. The Scottish government has initiatives in place to tackle poverty and inequalities.

Robbie Walsh, 25, was charged with assault causing serious harm to Mr. Haugh, who was stabbed and died in a fight involving three men in Kilkee. Two other arrested men were released without charge. Walsh was remanded in custody until August 14, with evidence of local tension following the incident.

Phil Flanagan, an MLA, tweeted a false accusation against Tom Elliott, a former UDR member and current MP, in May 2014. The tweet, which was deleted within an hour, implied that Elliott harassed and shot people during his service. Elliott, who has a clear MoD record, was alerted to the tweet by victims' campaigner Ann Travers and DUP assembly member Arlene Foster. Flanagan later apologized, admitting the tweet was untrue. The insurance firm covering MLAs refused to cover Flanagan for any compensation, leading to a separate court action. Despite the ordeal, Elliott expressed satisfaction with the outcome.

Hawick Knitwear, employing over 230 staff, increased its sweater production from 7,500 to 9,500 weekly due to high demand for its brand and private label clients. The company, founded in 1874, was acquired by Benny Hartop last year. Hawick Knitwear sells in Europe and internationally, including the USA, Canada, Mexico, and Japan. Mr. Hartop anticipates continued success due to dedicated staff and growing demand.

Sylvia Blackburn, 72, suffered serious head injuries after being hit by Brian Wright, 55, who claimed he was blinded by the sun. Wright, a lollipop lady for 20 years, admitted hitting Blackburn but denied causing serious injury through dangerous driving. The incident occurred when Blackburn stepped out to guide a woman and her daughter across the road during sunset. Wright could not recall if the traffic lights were red or green, and the sun was shining directly into his eyes. The trial is ongoing.

The passage discusses a Nato exercise named "Dynamic Mongoose" in response to the growing threat from Russian submarines. The exercise involves 10 Nato warships, including a Royal Navy Frigate, and anti-submarine warfare helicopters. The German U-boat U33, commanded by Kai Nicklesdorf, is trying to avoid detection while attempting to take out the command ship, the USS Vicksburg, and an oil tanker. The exercise highlights a gap in Britain's defences, as it no longer has any maritime patrol aircraft. The underwater unmanned vehicles or drones, named Harpo and Groucho, are also mentioned as aiding in the search. The purpose of the exercise is to ensure Nato is ready to conduct anti-submarine warfare, but it also underscores the need for nations like Britain to address their deficiencies.

United Nations officials are concerned about potential genocide and ethnic cleansing in South Sudan, the world's youngest country. Since July, violence in Juba and southern Equatoria states forced over 340,000 people to flee into neighboring Uganda, more than any other country this year. The UN reports that 2,500 South Sudanese become refugees daily. The violence, marked by killings, rape, and targeting of civilians along ethnic lines, has led to a massive influx of refugees into Uganda. Despite Uganda's generous response, supplying water to the refugees has become a problem. The international community is urged to pressure South Sudanese leaders to stop the violence.

McKenzie, 38, aims to win the English super-middleweight championship against Jahmaine Smyle on 12th November at York Hall. A former footballer who turned professional boxer in 2013, McKenzie has eight wins and one draw in nine fights. He is the son of Clinton, a former British and European champion, and trained by his uncle Duke, a three-time world champion.

Bridgwater Community Hospital is set to receive funding as part of a £330m investment for new NHS facilities in England. The new hospital will feature 30 inpatient beds, a midwifery-led maternity unit, a minor injury unit, and space for X-ray and mobile scanners. The current hospital, built in 1813, is outdated and cramped. The project cost is £33m, with the balance covered by NHS Somerset and Somerset Partnership NHS Foundation Trust. The new hospital aims to improve patient recovery and well-being, with construction planned to finish by autumn 2014.

A man was fatally shot outside a property on Daniel Hill Terrace, Upperthorpe, near Sheffield city centre. The victim, a family member, was either in or near a black Mercedes car he was driving when shot. This incident occurred during a family gathering, and the man was taken to the hospital but died from his injuries. This shooting is among several recent ones in Sheffield, but the others were in the city's northern areas.

The passage discusses the activities of three cyber groups involved in the conflict between Ukraine and Russia. The Ukrainian Cyber Troops, led by Yevhen Dokukin, are known for hacking into Russian servers and using DDoS attacks to disrupt rebel websites and electronic payment systems. Dokukin has also claimed to have hijacked CCTV systems and network printers to spread pro-Ukrainian messages. On the other side, Cyber Berkut, an anti-Western group, has targeted Ukrainian government websites, electronic billboards, and reportedly disrupted electronic vote-counting systems. They have also published confidential documents and messages suggesting Ukrainian involvement in the downing of Malaysia Airlines flight MH17. Lastly, Anonymous International, a group focused on Russia's domestic affairs, has published leaked documents and emails, some of which pertain to Ukraine. Their methods of obtaining information are unclear.

Tricia Marwick, Duncan McNeil, and Mr. Salmond are among the MSPs stepping down before the 5 May election. Mr. Salmond, former first minister, delivered a valedictory address emphasizing Scotland's diversity and unity, the need for the parliament to take greater responsibility, and the transfer of powers under the Scotland Bill. He also joked about competition from the UK budget and wished success to his political rivals. Duncan McNeil, a Scottish Labour backbencher, warned Holyrood to learn from Westminster's committee system and stressed the importance of accountability and scrutiny. Annabel Goldie, a former Scottish Conservative MSP, humorously mentioned her interactions with Finance Secretary John Swinney in her farewell speech.

Sarah Rochira, Older People's Commissioner for Wales, is conducting a review into the quality of life and care of older people in residential care. She plans to gather experiences from pensioners, their families, and care providers to develop recommendations. The review will consider factors like physical and psychological health, social relationships, and the care home environment. While the commissioner aims to highlight good care and address poor care, the care sector expressed disappointment over the lack of a care provider expert on the main advisory panel.

Harbro Group, based in Aberdeenshire, reported a pre-tax profit increase of £800,000 to £3.5m for the year ending June 2016. Despite a £1m decrease in turnover, international sales grew. Harbro manufactures feeds for various livestock sectors and operates 19 Country Store shops in Scotland, offering products for farming and rural communities. The company acknowledges challenging times in agriculture, partly due to Brexit, but remains optimistic about its future position.

A man in his 70s was found dead at a house in Nettleden Road, Little Gaddesden, near Berkhamsted, and a man in his 80s was hospitalized. The police are investigating the death as murder and want to question 55-year-old Ian John McLoughlin, known as Ian John Baker. Detectives urge people not to approach him and have advised residents to report any information. Ian is described as white, around 6ft tall, with greying hair, and believed to have been wearing sunglasses, blue jeans or three-quarter length trousers, and a specific shirt.

David Lipton, the IMF's second-in-command, warned of a weakening global economy at a delicate juncture, citing downgraded growth forecasts and China's declining exports. This situation impacts businesses and industries relying on China's growth.

The council leader announced that the Cowes crossing would be free until 2 July due to issues with a new chain ferry, which has experienced breakdowns, run aground, and caused vehicle damage. A review by auditors was ordered, and compensation for affected businesses and damaged cars is under discussion. The council authorized ramp extensions to prevent vehicles from scraping the concrete, and groundings were attributed to seamanship issues, which have been resolved.

A car crash on the southbound carriageway near the Hindhead tunnel at Bramshott, involving several vehicles, occurred at approximately 07:30 GMT on Thursday. A 32-year-old man was found dead at the scene. A 33-year-old man from Waterlooville was arrested on suspicion of causing death by driving without due care and attention. The road closure lasted until early evening for investigation purposes.

Matching Models, an international temp agency, faced criticism for its discriminatory job advertisements, including one seeking a personal assistant with specific physical attributes and another for a "sexy female driver." The Equality and Human Rights Commission (EHRC) condemned these practices as unlawful and demeaning to women. The agency's founder defended the ads as catering to clients' specific needs, but critics argue they violate equality legislation. The EHRC plans to address these hiring practices, and employment lawyers suggest such discriminatory ads could lead to legal action.

A hostel at the Pragati Residential School in Bangalore was the site of a shooting, where office assistant Mahesh allegedly shot two students, Gautami and Sirisha. The incident is unusual as gun crimes in Indian schools are rare. Mahesh was arrested after a manhunt and is awaiting trial until April 12th.

Glaad's analysis of shows from June 2016 to May 2017 revealed 278 regular LGBT characters, with an increase in transgender characters from 7 to 16. However, over 25 lesbian and bisexual female characters were killed off, including Poussey Washington and Bea Smith. The study also noted a record high percentage of black characters on broadcast TV, largely due to shows like Empire, Luke Cage, and How to Get Away with Murder.

David Mackintosh, a Conservative MP for Northampton South, announced his decision to not seek re-election due to criticism over a £10.25m public loan to Northampton Town FC, which is now missing and under police investigation. The local party expressed a desire to deselect him, and he acknowledged it was time for new representation.

Roy Oliver, a 37-year-old fired a rifle into a car, killing 15-year-old Jordan Edwards during a police response to an underage drinking party in Dallas. Oliver was fired for policy violations and charged with four counts of aggravated assault with a deadly weapon. He faces five to 99 years in prison if convicted, potentially becoming the first convicted police officer of murder in Dallas County since 1973.

The passage discusses Melania Trump's decision to move to Washington with her son Barron after finishing school, a move not unprecedented in the history of the United States. Melania's decision has sparked criticism and speculation, but also support, as some believe it aligns with responsible parenting. Melania has indicated that Barron is her top priority, and she may not take on the full-time role of her predecessors. The first lady's role is ceremonial, but it is vital to the public's perception of the president. Melania is interested in tackling cyber-bullying.

A 72-year-old man died in Inverness, prompting an investigation into the police response to his call. The Police Investigations and Review Commissioner (Pirc) is scrutinizing the initial police response, with Police Scotland fully engaged in the investigation. The Crown Office and Procurator Fiscal Service (COPFS) has instructed Pirc to conduct this investigation and submit a report.

A yellow wind warning was issued, predicting gusts up to 75mph, especially to the west of the mountains, with an unusual easterly direction potentially intensifying the impact. Forecasters anticipate disruptions to travel on roads and at sea. The affected counties include Conwy, Anglesey, Gwynedd, Pembrokeshire, Carmarthenshire, Ceredigion, and Powys. A tree fell in Menai Bridge, Anglesey, causing Telford Road to close for cleanup.

The Giants had a challenging start with Derrick Walser as player-coach, but Jeff Dimmen evened the score for the Panthers. Mike Forney and Andy Bohmback swapped leads in the second period. Mike Radja and James Desmarais extended the lead to 4-2, but Nottingham's David Ling scored a rebound. The two teams are set to face each other again in a Saturday night match as part of a double-header, with Nottingham currently leading the league.

Hamilton, starting from last due to a broken front wing and multiple pit stops, faces a 36-point deficit to overtake Rosberg in the remaining 18 races. Sebastian Vettel, despite a collision, finished second and faced criticism from Kvyat. Raikkonen, after a damaged car incident, managed to pass Hamilton and benefit from Ferrari's soft tyre strategy. Hamilton's progress was hindered by car damage and a challenging race against Rosberg, who maintained a lead.

Thomas Hitzlsperger, a former footballer, publicly revealed his homosexuality in an interview with Die Zeit, becoming the most prominent German footballer to do so. His announcement was praised by fellow footballers, including Lukas Podolski and Arne Friedrich, as well as German football administration figures like Theo Zwanziger and Reinhard Rauball. Hitzlsperger's decision was seen as a significant step towards combating homophobia in German football. Despite this progress, the issue of homosexuality in football remains a sensitive topic, as evidenced by the controversial remarks of former Germany captain Philipp Lahm. The announcement was supported by German Chancellor Angela Merkel's spokesman and openly gay politician Volker Beck, who hoped it would encourage others to come out.

Sidwell, a 34-year-old midfielder, has contributed significantly to Brighton's promotion to the Premier League after 34 years, making 32 Championship appearances. Hoping for a new contract, he aims to stay with the club in the top flight. Previously loaned to Albion and having played in the Premier League with several clubs, Sidwell believes he deserves another chance at the top level.

The passage describes a soccer match between Blackpool and Colchester United, which ended in a draw, 1-1. Key events include Blackpool's Nathan Delfouneso and Kurtis Guthrie scoring, Colchester's goalkeeper Sam Slocombe making crucial saves, and several fouls and free kicks. The match saw penalties, red cards, and substitutions, with both teams finishing with 10 men due to injuries.

A 29-year-old player, likely Reid due to context, made 37 appearances for Sky Blues in the previous season when they were relegated. Reid has played for Charlton, Bradford, and Preston before potentially debuting for U's in an EFL Cup match against Aston Villa. Colchester suffered a 3-1 loss to Accrington at the start of their season.

PC Keith Palmer's murder led to the UK Police Memorial Trust appealing for £1.5m to construct a permanent memorial at the National Memorial Arboretum, Staffordshire. The memorial will honor over 1,400 officers and staff, with a £1m government commitment towards the £4m needed. It will be dedicated to fallen officers over the past 250 years, with a brass screen for personal remembrance. Expected completion by 2019.

United leads with 15 points, 8 games left, after a 1-0 win against Sunderland. Despite injuries to Rafael, Anderson, and goalkeeper David De Gea, Ferguson remains focused on the upcoming game against Manchester City. United has a 15-point lead over City and aims to surpass Chelsea's 95-point record. Changes are expected for the FA Cup quarter-final replay at Chelsea, with Wayne Rooney's fitness uncertain.

Mr. Schmidt, Google's representative, stated that the company legally paid £10m in UK corporate taxes from 2006 to 2011 and believes taxes are not optional. He mentioned that Google would comply with any changes in the UK tax laws and suggested that taxes should be levied where economic activity occurs. Margaret Hodge proposed a new committee to oversee major firms' tax arrangements, including secret evidence hearings. Google, routinely routing sales through Ireland, faces criticism for tax minimization. EU leaders agreed to address tax avoidance through information exchange between tax authorities. Schmidt advocates for legislators to set rules and calls for international tax reform debate.

NHS Improvement aims to reduce agency staff costs by £1bn by the end of the current financial year, following a £3.6bn expenditure last year. A cap introduced in October saved £600m, limiting hospital payments to 55% above normal rates for staff, excluding senior managers. Despite progress, NHS trusts are 10% behind target, and it's unclear if other pay expenses have increased. NHS Improvement plans to publish agency spending league tables and collect data on top earners.

The Longford Town Centre, originally envisioned as a hub of commerce, now symbolizes the economic downturn in Ireland. Despite challenges, local businesses like Matt O'Brien's men's clothing shop are noticing a gradual improvement. However, the main opposition party criticizes the government's handling of the midlands, particularly the delayed implementation of water meters. They argue for a more targeted approach to attract foreign investment. The government, on the other hand, highlights potential employment opportunities from the proposed Center Parcs development. Overall, while signs of recovery are emerging, there is a consensus that more efforts are needed to bolster the local economy.

The passage details a cricket tournament concluding on May 29th, with eight teams competing in a double round-robin format. The top four teams advance to the playoffs. Key players include Warner, Kohli, and De Villiers for runs, and McClenaghan, Kumar, and Rahman for wickets. Four England players participate, and the schedule includes fixtures and results from April 25th to May 29th.

The Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs reported a 200 million increase in plastic carrier bags since 2013. Due to recycling issues, these bags often end up in landfills and waterways, harming the environment. Starting in October, England will charge 5p for plastic bags to promote reuse, a measure that has previously reduced bag usage in Wales, Scotland, and Northern Ireland. Environmentalists hope this will decrease bag waste in England.

Hundreds of homes in Wales faced power cuts, train delays, and speed restrictions due to strong winds. Part of a school roof was damaged near Caernarfon, and Irish Ferries canceled six sailings between Holyhead and Dublin. The National Trust closed two castles, and a Boxing Day Dip event in Denbighshire was postponed.

Michael B. Jordan is excited to work on a new project with Creed director Ryan Coogler and Captain America: Civil War's Black Panther actor Chadwick Boseman. He previously played the Human Torch in Fantastic Four. Jordan will also collaborate with Oscar-winning actress Lupita Nyong'o, known for her role in 12 Years a Slave. The film, featuring the characters from Star Wars: The Force Awakens, is set for release in February 2018.

The theatre and BBC studios at Alexandra Palace, dating back to 1875, are set to be restored and repurposed for performances, screenings, comedy, and music. Funded by the Heritage Lottery Fund, Haringey Council, and the Alexandra Park and Palace Charitable Trust, the project aims to reopen the theatre in 2018 as part of a larger restoration effort. The refurbished east wing will include a public space and exhibition area, with the entire project costing £26.6m.

The former Manchester City player, now 30, has 61 caps for England, making his debut in 2009. He participated in two World Cups and two European Championships, but only played briefly in Euro 2016. Milner holds the record for most capped England Under-21 player with 46 caps. He scored his only international goal in England's 5-0 win over Moldova during the 2014 Fifa World Cup qualifiers.

Marcy Smith and her family in Glovertown, Newfoundland and Labrador, survived a house fire caused by Smith burning rubbish in the wood stove. The fire, which started quickly and engulfed the house, was unnoticed by the family due to a non-functioning alarm. Their only clothing was pyjamas as they escaped. Their dog and cat did not survive. The community supported them with donations. Smith's son, David, who was awake and alerted the family, is praised for his role in their survival.

The energy drinks company was considering a £200m offer for West Ham Premier League club, which Sullivan and Gold own majority stake in since 2010. They own over 85% of the club, and despite potential debt clearance through minority shareholding sale, they plan to pass ownership to their children.

The passage describes an event where the Oscars were not the focus. Instead, it was a fan-voted awards ceremony that also promoted upcoming summer blockbusters. The Fault in Our Stars won best movie and actress, while Bradley Cooper won best male performance. Other winners included Shailene Woodley, Channing Tatum, Meryl Streep, Jennifer Lopez, Jennifer Lawrence, Seth Rogen, and Rose Byrne. Kevin Hart accepted an award for comedic performance, and Robert Downey Jr. received the Generation Award. The event also previewed upcoming films like Pitch Perfect sequel, Trainwreck, and Ultron.

Cammy Smith, a Scotland Under-21 player, was loaned from Dundee United to St Mirren in July. He has five goals in his current season and made his debut for Aberdeen in 2012, scoring four times in 89 appearances. St Mirren's manager, Jack Ross, considers this acquisition excellent as it provides another attacking option for the team.
Northumberland County Council plans to repair 145 potholes daily for four months using Jetpatcher machines. Additional staff will address damaged drainage systems and clear gutters due to heavy rain.

In December 2016, six Wood Group employees working on EnQuest's Thistle platform off Shetland were exposed to low levels of naturally occurring radioactive material (NORM) during shutdown activities. The exposure was less than 1% of the reportable level, and EnQuest informed the Health and Safety Executive (HSE). Following the incident, EnQuest implemented additional precautionary measures, and Wood Group conducted medical assessments for their employees. The workers, including rigging supervisor Steve Innes, expressed concerns over potential long-term harm and alleged that EnQuest failed in its duty of care. Unite union criticized the treatment of the workers, emphasizing the need for transparency in serious safety incidents. The HSE stated that the incident was not reportable under the current RIDDOR system, and no separate investigation was conducted.

The Asian Civilisation Museum (ACM) returned a sculpture of Hindu goddess Uma Parameshvari to India after admitting it was potentially stolen. The museum bought the artwork from a New York dealer in 2007, but it was later revealed that the dealer's manager confessed to selling stolen Indian antiquities. The ASI requested the return of the sculpture in May, and the museum plans to seek legal compensation for the incident.

A magnitude-4.8 earthquake hit near Lucca, Italy, causing aftershocks and power outages in the Garfagnana area. The quake, felt in Milan, Florence, and other cities, had no immediate casualties or damage. Italy, prone to seismic activity, experienced a deadly 6.0 magnitude quake in 2009, leading to convictions for officials who downplayed the risks.
On 8th September 2016, Austin Grant from Sheffield expressed joy after witnessing positive results in growing unripe fruit in South Yorkshire's climate.

Rockstar delayed the release of Grand Theft Auto V until March 24 due to additional testing and polishing. Despite the postponement, online heists will be available on consoles before the PC version. The PC release promises enhanced detail, with Los Santos and Blaine County viewable in 1080p at 60fps. The game's minimum PC specifications were also disclosed. GTA V became the fastest-selling entertainment product, generating $1bn in just three days upon its initial release in 2013.

The 76-year-old artist, who won the £25,000 John Moores Painting Prize for his work "Squint (19)" displayed at Liverpool's Walker Art Gallery, was one of the 1991 shortlisted artists. This win was particularly meaningful as Simpson had been longlisted three times before. The painting, described as "quite extraordinary" and "difficult to look at", depicts a leper squinting through a medieval church hole. Simpson plans to use the prize money for art supplies. "Squint (19)" is part of a series, and its smaller size was a deliberate choice for the competition. The John Moores Painting Prize, established in 1957, is a prestigious British art award.

Yeni Safak and Yeni Akit offices were attacked by four masked assailants early Thursday, causing no casualties. Both buildings' windows were shattered, and numerous bullet casings were found. The police are searching for the attackers, and no group has claimed responsibility. This incident is reminiscent of a similar attack on Hurriyet's offices last September.

A 24-year-old, previously under contract with the Stags, will join Bignot's team on a free transfer from Crawley, where he scored three goals in 23 games. This move becomes Bignot's first signing for the Mariners, starting from 1 January.

Arsène Wenger, whose contract expires in summer, has not commented on potential job offers. Former England manager Sam Allardyce was replaced by Gareth Southgate in September. Southgate led England to a 2-0 win against Malta and a draw with Slovenia. Wenger praised Southgate's experience and decision-making skills. Southgate, 46, has a World Cup qualifier and a friendly match to secure a permanent position with the Football Association. Wenger stated that Hector Bellerin, 21, would be offered a new contract by Arsenal, despite interest from Barcelona and Manchester City. Aaron Ramsey, 25, will miss one or two more games due to a hamstring injury.

A local man working at Fruehauf on Houghton Road in Lincolnshire fell from a cherry picker around 13:45 GMT on a Thursday. The incident is being jointly investigated by Lincolnshire Police and the Health and Safety Executive, with Fruehauf fully cooperating.

Transport Minister Humza Yousaf announced a new charter arrangement to resolve the dispute over seafarers' pay, which involved workers on two freight boats allegedly earning less than £4 an hour. The change will transfer contracted services from Seatruck back to Serco Northlink, starting next month. Seatruck had contended that the national minimum wage didn't apply to their crew, many of whom were non-UK residents. Despite Serco Northlink's attempts to bridge the pay gap, Seatruck declined. The new arrangements aim to ensure all crew members receive at least the minimum wage. This agreement follows Serco Northlink's six-year £243m contract to operate three ferries and two cargo boats to the Northern Isles, heavily subsidized by the Scottish government.

Ken Dickie, 64, died six days after a fight at Rockley Park, involving Jamie Mitchell, 35, who admitted common assault and perverting justice by lying about the incident. The altercation occurred during a visit to the park, where tensions escalated after consuming alcohol.

Rod Temperton, nicknamed "The Invisible Man," was a prolific songwriter who passed away at 66 due to cancer in London. He wrote hits for Michael Jackson, Heatwave, and others, including "Off The Wall," "Baby Be Mine," and "Boogie Nights." Temperton's work earned him Grammy and Oscar nominations, and he left a significant impact on the music industry.

Dr Neil Loader and Emeritus Prof Alayne Street-Perrott, from Swansea University, discovered ancient earthworks, possibly 2,000 years old, in Acre state, western Brazil. The team, including researchers from Exeter, Reading, and Brazil's SÃ£o Paulo, Belém universities, found over 450 large geometrical "geoglyphs" concealed by rainforest until deforestation revealed them. The purpose of these sites is unclear, as they lack defensive structures and artefacts. Dr Loader's analysis suggests they were built amongst taller vegetation, not visible above the forest canopy. The research challenges the idea of pristine Amazonian forests prior to European arrival in the 16th century, indicating human influence over 6,000 years. The team suggests ancient "agroforestry" practices may still influence Acre's biodiversity.

Novak Kyrgios, an Australian ranked 12th, defeated world number 29 Querrey 6-4 6-4 in 53 minutes to advance to the second round. Kyrgios attributed his lack of usual vocal demeanor to tiredness and a tough match. His recent win at the Japan Open is pushing him closer to the top 10. Kyrgios also mentioned the physical toll of his success and travel, including a late arrival and poor sleep, as contributing factors to his current state.

Scientists and charities urge the Welsh government to extend the HPV vaccine to boys, as it could protect against increasing head and neck cancers. HPV, a sexually transmitted virus, is currently vaccinated against in girls aged 12-13 to prevent cervical cancer. The Welsh government awaits advice from the Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunisation before making any changes to the current vaccination program.

Jak Trueman, 15, battled gamma delta T-cell lymphoma, a rare form of blood cancer. Despite his illness, he attended his school prom for 10 minutes and shared his journey on social media, gaining over 28,000 Likes. He was known for his love of Rangers FC and positive attitude. Jak's family received the Bronze Duke of Edinburgh Award and Kerry MacGregor Memorial Trophy for his resilience. Despite his family's efforts to raise funds for Leukaemia & Lymphoma Research, Jak's cancer had spread throughout his body by January 23rd, and doctors decided not to pursue further treatment.

In a game lacking in chances, Egyptian player Mohamed Salah assisted El Said, who scored past Uganda goalkeeper Denis Onyango. Uganda's Joseph Ochaya had a goal disallowed for offside earlier. Egypt's win puts them against Ghana for top spot in Group D, while Uganda is out of the tournament since 1978. Egypt struggled against Uganda's defense, but Salah's composure led to Egypt's only goal. Uganda, on the other hand, faces Mali in their final game, needing a win and specific conditions to qualify. The match ended with Egypt 1, Uganda 0.

Lancashire County Council plans to acquire land from the former Glenburn Sports College and Skelmersdale College for a new transport hub. This decision comes after a study by Network Rail, with Skelmersdale potentially receiving two direct trains per hour to Liverpool. The preferred location offers room for future expansion and good connectivity. Skelmersdale, a large town without its own railway station since 1956, was designated a new town in 1961.
Plants discovered in an elaborate grow house during a warehouse search near Ashbourne led to a man in his late 40s' arrest.

A 28-year-old woman of Kurdish origin from Hamelin, Lower Saxony, was found severely injured on a pavement after being dragged by the neck through several streets. Her ex-partner, a 38-year-old man from Bad Muender, also of Kurdish origin, was later arrested. The motive behind the attack remains unknown.

The study found that women are equally likely as men to request a pay rise, but are less likely to receive one. This challenges the "reticent female" theory and the idea that women avoid asking for more money due to fear of upsetting their boss or deviating from gender stereotypes. Factors such as employer size, industry, parenthood, and qualifications were considered. The study, based on Australian workplace relations data, suggests some level of discrimination against women. However, younger women are increasingly successful in negotiating pay rises.

Oxford City Council has struggled to find suitable new burial sites due to factors like site size, ground conditions, high water tables, and restrictive covenants. Despite ground investigations, all council-owned sites identified have been discarded. With only two cemeteries left (Wolvercote and Botley), they are projected to be full by 2018 and 2021. The council is still searching for options, but once these cemeteries are full, only family plots, reserved plots, and ashes interment will be possible. The last increase in burial space was in 1932.

The Hebridean Celtic Festival in Stornoway, from 19-22 July, will offer an augmented reality app for visitors. This app will provide online access to information from signs and posters, videos, band interviews, and more. It also allows global interaction with the festival, instant access to information, ticket purchases, and a taste of the festival's atmosphere.

A 10-year-old Irish-bred horse tragically died after winning the Cotswold Chase at Cheltenham, despite having no significant underlying health issues. The horse suffered a severe pulmonary haemorrhage, a rare occurrence in sport horses. Many Clouds, who showed no symptoms of post-race ataxia on the day of the race, had previously won prestigious races and had received treatment for overheating, but his death raised questions about a possible link to his condition.

A 15-year-old girl, now 34 and called Davina, was accused of raping a man named David Ayrton in 2004 when she was 15. Ayrton, who has learning difficulties and attempted suicide, denies the charge. He stated that the victim did not physically alter her body or take medication. Davina was remanded into custody and is likely to be held at a male prison in Winchester. The court heard that the victim shouted and swore at Davina to stop the attack, but her friends did not wake up. The victim also mentioned that she had only consumed a can and a half of Foster's during the incident.

The Serbian team, including world number one Djokovic, lost to Brazilians Marcelo Melo and Bruno Soares with scores 6-4 6-4. This was after Djokovic's surprise third-round defeat at Wimbledon and his earlier loss in the singles to Juan Martin del Potro. Despite these setbacks, Djokovic later won his 30th Masters title in Toronto.

Over 20 participants from various countries will compete in a chainsaw carving event in Carrbridge, Cairngorms. The competition, which includes Scotland, England, Ireland, Europe, Canada, and the US, only allows the use of chainsaws. Contestants aim to carve log shapes of animals and people. Pete Bowsher from Moffat, last year's winner, will defend his title and prize, the Claymore Trophy.

Webb, a 27-year-old Welsh rugby player, is recovering from a foot injury sustained during a World Cup warm-up in September. He is nearing a return to play, with plans to get fit before the Six Nations in February. Webb has renewed his contract with Ospreys and Wales, turning down other offers. He made his debut for Ospreys in 2007 and is committed to playing for both his club and country.

Two men were stopped by US border agents near the border for attempting to smuggle 58lb of MDMA from Canada to San Francisco. One man fired at the agents and fled, while the other, Jeffrey Laviolette, was arrested. Nathan Hall, a Canadian citizen, was also arrested with a backpack containing the drugs. A woman, Kali Henifin, and her boyfriend, Ryan Lambert, were arrested for planning to pick up the men and transport the drugs. They face charges of conspiracy, drug possession, and distribution.

The NSPCC's Childline service counselled over 4,500 children in the past year, a significant increase from 2,400 in 2011-12. The charity highlighted the prevalence of online abuse, with some children as young as seven victims. Online trolls cause distress and humiliation, and cyberbullying can persist beyond school hours. Dame Esther Rantzen emphasized the need for adult intervention and serious attention from schools. The report coincides with Anti-Bullying Week, with the Anti Bullying Alliance working to address the issue. Young people advised dealing with bullying by seeking help, as standing up for oneself can be challenging.

The US abstained from vetoing a UN Security Council resolution demanding an end to Israeli settlement construction, a move that angered Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu. Netanyahu claimed the White House influenced the resolution's language and pushed for its approval. Despite Israel's rejection of the resolution, US Secretary of State John Kerry was set to address the Israel-Palestinian conflict, aiming to counter Israeli criticisms of the Obama administration. The resolution, which Israel considers illegal, was supported by the US and 14 other countries. It stated that settlements hinder the two-state solution and peace. In response, Israel summoned ambassadors, cut aid, and postponed a housing vote in Jerusalem. The resolution was seen as a step towards the upcoming Middle East peace conference.

In a BBC interview, the subject praised the Queen as a "guiding example" of a good monarch, especially on the eve of her 90th birthday. The Queen, accompanied by the Duke of Edinburgh, participated in various events to celebrate her birthday, including meeting staff, viewing an exhibition, and marking the 500th anniversary of the postal service. Prince William also spoke highly of the Queen, stating she was a good role model for him. Despite recent negative press about his own engagement with royal duties, William emphasized his commitment to his responsibilities. The Queen's family was featured on stamps released to commemorate her birthday, and she will continue to be celebrated with events and beacons across the UK and worldwide. However, the republican group Republic criticized the BBC for its coverage, claiming it was unfair and biased towards the monarchy.

Cheltenham Town, after a promising start, ended up with a 0-2 loss to West Ham United. The match saw two quick goals from Diafra Sakho and Andre Ayew, giving West Ham the early lead. Despite several near-misses and attempts, Cheltenham Town failed to score. West Ham's key moments included a saved header by James Collins and a high and wide shot by Pedro Obiang. The match also saw several fouls, free kicks, and substitutions. Cheltenham Town's exit from the EFL Cup ended their representation in the competition.

Aidan McNicholl, a 36-year-old hospital radiographer, died in a collision on the A5 at Cerrigydrudion. The driver, Andreas Werner, 46, from Leipzig, caused the crash by failing to notice a motorcyclist while turning his VW Transporter. Werner pleaded guilty to causing death by careless driving in Llandudno Magistrates' Court, receiving a £1,000 fine and a two-year driving ban in the UK. Despite this, Werner's family did not see the value in imprisonment, considering it a momentary mistake. Werner expressed remorse and could not explain the crash.

Imran Khawaja, a 27-year-old British fighter in Syria, is facing up to life imprisonment for his role in the conflict. Known as Abu Daigham al-Britani, Khawaja was a prominent member of Rayat al Tawheed, a group affiliated with Islamic State. He was involved in producing propaganda materials and appeals for donations. Khawaja attempted to return to the UK last year, faking his death online and trying to remain undetected. He was apprehended at Dover, and while his exact activities in Syria remain unknown, he is considered one of the most dangerous British jihadists.

Jackson, 22, scored four goals in 36 appearances last season for Wrexham, which finished eighth. He is set to join Barnsley as their third signing for the next season, with a play-off final at Wembley on Sunday. He declined a contract offer from Wrexham for the upcoming season.

National Trust volunteers are clearing sealed bottles of detergent that washed up on Poldhu Cove and nearby coves in Cornwall, potentially from a container lost during stormy weather. The Maritime and Coastguard Agency states there's no evidence linking these bottles to a specific container lost near Land's End. Conservationists express concern for marine life, and the public is advised to maintain a safe distance from any more bottles that may appear.

A car crash on the A9 north of Berriedale in Caithness around 14:00 resulted in several minor injuries. The road was subsequently closed, and diversions were established via the A897 Helmsdale to Melvich road. Police Scotland is still investigating the incident.

Dervite, a 28-year-old French centre-back, made 14 appearances last season, helping Wanderers finish second in League One and secure promotion. He joined Bolton from Charlton in 2014 and has made 83 appearances in all competitions. Following their promotion, Dervite, along with David Wheater, Gary Madine, and Jem Karacan, signed new contracts with Bolton.

Lord Oates, a Lib Dem, accused Labour of giving false hope and being willing to concede everything. The two parties had previously cooperated to defeat government proposals regarding EU citizens' rights and Brexit deal approval. However, this alliance ended when MPs rejected these amendments. A Labour source criticized the Lib Dems' actions as grandstanding for campaign purposes. Despite past cooperation, the Labour source anticipated ongoing tensions between the two parties.

The passage discusses the UK's decreasing priority on defense in political agendas, despite global instability and defense cuts. Key points include:

1. Defense is not a priority for most political parties, with the sentiment reflected in opinion polls.
2. Defense spending has decreased, with the UK falling to sixth in global defense spending.
3. The UK is making significant cuts to its armed forces, including the size of the regular Army and the number of warships and front-line fast jet squadrons.
4. The UK has capability gaps, such as the lack of Maritime Patrol Aircraft, and relies on Nato allies for certain defense tasks.
5. The UK's commitment to spending 2% of its GDP on defense is absent, with only two smaller parties pledging to meet this goal.
6. The UK's defense spending is projected to fall below the NATO threshold, and further cuts are expected.
7. Political parties are backing away from further big cuts, with some focusing on renewing the UK's nuclear deterrent.
8.

Barcelona, the Spanish champions, deny any offense in relation to the signing of Neymar, despite a judge's decision to continue investigations. The club claims the tax payment was in line with their fiscal obligations, but the actual cost of Neymar, including various fees and payments, totals £106.8m. Despite these allegations, Neymar has performed well for Barcelona, scoring seven goals in 18 league matches and three in seven Champions League games.

Michael Luciw, a 27-year-old father from Nottingham, tragically lost his life in a motorway crash caused by a driver, Albert Kenneth Newman, who was on the wrong way. Newman, who was over 70, had to renew his license every three years without medical or driving tests. The Luciw family advocates for regular driving tests for older people, citing slowed reactions with age. They believe this could prevent accidents like the one that took Michael's life, who was described as generous and looking forward to his daughter's milestones.

The passage discusses concerns over the safety of transvaginal mesh implants used to treat incontinence, with over 20,000 women in Scotland having undergone the procedure. Two patients resigned from the review group due to dissatisfaction with the final report, which recommended not routinely offering the procedure to women with pelvic organ prolapse. Instead, patients should be presented with various treatments and informed to make educated decisions. The report also suggested mandatory reporting of adverse events. Despite calls for a ban, the recommendations will continue to be implemented. Independent review chairwoman Tracey Gillies apologized for not achieving consensus, admitting the task was challenging.

Laura Muir, 23, broke McColgan's 25-year-old record by 14 seconds with a time of 14 minutes, 49.12 seconds in a mixed 3K race at the Emirates Arena in Glasgow. Despite initial concerns about the race meeting all criteria for record-breaking attempts, British Athletics confirmed Muir's time would be classified as official. McColgan praised Muir's potential to win world medals and noted similarities between Muir's race and her own record-breaking race 25 years ago.

Jung won a medal in the Rio Olympics riding Sam, a replacement for Fischertakinou who had an infection. France's Astier Nicolas won silver, while Phillip Dutton from the USA took bronze. GB's William Fox-Pitt, who had been in an induced coma just 10 months prior, finished 12th. Despite a faultless final show-jumping phase, Fox-Pitt's overall performance was affected by a poor cross-country phase.

Andy Murray won against Fognini with scores of 6-2, 4-6, 6-1, 7-5 after two hours and 39 minutes. Murray, the 2nd seed, managed to win five games consecutively to avoid a fifth set. This victory secured Murray's place in the last 16 for the 11th time. Murray will face French player Benoit Paire in the fourth round. Meanwhile, Johanna Konta, another British player, reached the second week for the first time with a 6-4, 6-1 win over Maria Sakkari. Murray admitted the match was tense and challenging, especially as it got darker. Despite Fognini's efforts, he couldn't maintain his pace and eventually lost the set due to errors and a visible obscenity penalty.

On 6 October 2014, paramedics responded to a sudden death at Joe's Bar in Dungiven, where alcohol was served past licensing hours. Colleen O'Neill, the license holder, and James Thomas were charged with allowing liquor consumption outside licensed times. The judge ordered the bar's closure for three months, citing Ms. O'Neill's poor record. Both were fined, with Ms. O'Neill receiving £3,000 and Mr. Thomas £1,000.

Mike Nesbitt, launching the Ulster Unionists' manifesto, emphasized partnership over domination and stated that the election should focus on the Renewable Heat Incentive scandal. He expressed no regrets over his comments, which led to laughter and reaffirmation from his colleague Danny Kennedy. Nesbitt urged voters to choose Ulster Unionists first, then any candidate they believe will act rightly. He denied any mistake and highlighted the manifesto's points, including tackling waiting lists, increasing police numbers, and addressing Brexit concerns. The election was framed as a referendum on Stormont's handling of the Renewable Heat Incentive, amidst controversy over Nesbitt's remarks about potentially transferring to the SDLP.

Justice Minister Claire Sugden announced a motion for the assembly to approve, aligning Northern Ireland with England and Wales regarding automatic pardons for now-abolished sexual offences. Named 'Turing's Law', it permits both posthumous and living gay and bisexual men to apply for pardons. The minister secured executive agreement for this legislative consent motion, aiming for equal treatment and earlier resolution than an assembly bill. The motion is now under assembly consideration.

Yvonne Murray, a 23-year-old from Kinross, secured second place in a race with a time of 4:19.12, surpassing her own 1994 Scottish record of 4:22.60 and placing second on the British all-time list. This achievement also earned her the Scottish 1500m and mile records. Murray, who finished fifth in the previous year's World Championships, is now aiming for an Olympic place in Rio and is set to compete in further races, including a 1500m event in Stockholm.
The passage provides images from Scotland's top 26 beaches, noted for their excellent water quality.

The passage discusses the 2006 murder of Mr. Litvinenko in London, who was allegedly poisoned by suspects Dmitry Kovtun and Andrei Lugovoi with polonium-210. Barrister Richard Horwell QC stated that the Russian state likely sponsored the murder, although he did not directly accuse Russian President Vladimir Putin. Horwell also mentioned that Litvinenko had defected to the UK and made personal attacks on Putin. Despite the evidence, extradition attempts failed, and the suspects remain in Russia. Horwell also expressed uncertainty about the potential danger to the public from polonium radiation and the long-term effects.

Steve Smith, 26, is appointed as the captain of Australia's Twenty20 team due to Aaron Finch's injury. He will also captain the one-day team, succeeding Michael Clarke who retired after Australia lost the Ashes. Smith, highly regarded by selectors, has been vice-captained by David Warner, who has overcome past disciplinary issues. Smith and Warner will lead Australia in upcoming limited-overs matches.

David Farron, leader of the Liberal Democrats, refuses to label homosexual sex as a sin but is passionate about LGBT-plus rights and equal marriage. He aims to extend marital rights for transgender individuals and voted against the 2007 Equality Bill due to concerns about individual liberties, though he supports equality for all sexualities.

Sanofi closed its drug manufacturing site in Fawdon in 2015, resulting in 450 job losses. Accord Healthcare is now planning to use the site for its pharmaceutical production, potentially offering many of these positions to former Sanofi employees. The company's investment is expected to positively impact the area. Accord Healthcare, a global pharmaceutical company, develops and distributes over 130 products worldwide, and this move is seen as a boost to the local economy in Newcastle and the North East.

Richard Ellis, Ciaran Monaghan, and Ewan Sutherland are departing the council under a voluntary redundancy and early retirement scheme. Their roles include former interim director of corporate governance, head of the chief executive's office, and head of human resources and customer services respectively. The SNP group leader criticizes the council for losing senior staff and anticipates more departures. The council chief executive appreciates their dedication and professionalism.

Martin, an English rider, decided not to participate in road racing on Hondas for the year due to mechanical issues and a crash at the TT. He clarified this on Facebook after initially stating he was quitting road racing. Additionally, he will not compete in the upcoming Ulster Grand Prix.

The All Progressives Congress (APC) won 19 out of 28 governor posts in Nigeria's recent elections, marking a significant defeat for the Peoples Democratic Party (PDP). APC leader Muhammadu Buhari is set to be inaugurated on 29 May after defeating President Goodluck Jonathan. The PDP managed to secure eight governorships, mostly in the south-east. However, the APC failed to win in any of Nigeria's five oil-producing states, a concern for President-elect Buhari due to potential disruptions in oil production. The PDP's influence is now considered regional, and the party is expected to undergo introspection and rebuilding under a new leader. Despite some violence and allegations of corruption, the elections were relatively peaceful compared to previous years.

Mighty, a US-based environmental group, accuses Olam and Temasek, a Singapore state-owned investment company, of indirectly supporting unsustainable palm oil trading practices. These practices allegedly contribute to the haze affecting Singapore, Malaysia, and Indonesia. Olam, which sources 99% of its palm oil from third parties, is accused of creating a "secretive market" for rogue palm oil companies. However, Olam denies these allegations, stating it has a strict no-burn policy and only agreed to release the names of its 14 suppliers after pressure from Mighty. Temasek, as Olam's majority stakeholder, denies direct involvement in the company's operations. The report also mentions Olam's joint ventures in Gabon, where it is accused of clearing rainforests for palm oil plantations. Olam counters by saying it operates responsibly and transparently in Gabon.
On August 27, 2016, a restaurant started offering "puppy platters" following a new law permitting dogs to dine outdoors at eateries.

Fernando Forestieri is doubtful to play due to a knee issue and has only been on the bench in recent games. Derby County's David Nugent may return from a groin injury after missing a game. Jacob Butterfield, a midfielder, is seeking a return after scoring as a substitute.

Pakistan's telecoms regulator lifted the YouTube ban as Google introduced a Pakistan-specific version, despite YouTube denying authorities' content filtering capabilities. Young Pakistanis welcomed the decision, but some activists demanded transparency in Google and government agreements. The Pakistan Telecommunication Authority directed ISPs to provide YouTube access, which Google complied with under certain conditions. The ban, initially imposed in 2012 due to a controversial film, reflects Pakistan's strict blasphemy laws.

Domenico Scala, Swiss-Italian and head of Fifa's Ad-Hoc Electoral Committee, is one of five presidential candidates. He previously excused himself from 2015 elections due to nationality conflict with Swiss candidate Sepp Blatter. Liberian Musa Bility threatens to take Scala to the Court of Arbitration for Sport if he doesn't withdraw by Thursday, citing potential conflict of interest. Scala's representative argues no such conflict exists, as per Fifa regulations. The election to replace Blatter, Fifa's long-standing president, is set for Zurich with five candidates including Prince Ali and Gianni Infantino.

Daniel Timbers, 29, and Barry Joy, 56, were killed at Harford Attachments in a flashover explosion while working in a paint-spraying area. Their bodies were removed on Tuesday, and investigations suggest the explosion was caused by toxic fumes and ignition.

Tunisia initially faced expulsion from the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations due to a complaint lodged against Caf during the 2015 Nations Cup. However, they apologized and were allowed to participate. Morocco, on the other hand, was initially banned from the 2017 Nations Cup qualifying draw due to a similar complaint lodged against them. However, the Court of Arbitration for Sport overturned this ban, reducing their fine and allowing them to participate. Both nations expressed optimism for the future of African football. Tunisia had a controversial incident during the 2015 Nations Cup, which led to their complaint against Caf. However, they never accused Caf or the referee of corruption. Tunisia's participation in the 2017 Nations Cup seemed uncertain until a meeting with Caf president Issa Hayatou led to a resolution.

In the 95th minute of the game at Etihad Stadium, Chelsea won 3-1 after City's Sergio Aguero and Fernandinho were sent off. Cesc Fabregas, a Chelsea player, won't face further action. Aguero received a four-match ban for violent conduct, while Fernandinho will serve a three-match ban. Pep Guardiola apologized for his team's actions, and both clubs have until 18:00 GMT on 8th December to respond to the charge.

The passage discusses the importance of family in diagnosing diseases, as stated by Dr. Gareth Davies. It highlights that family members often notice symptoms before medical professionals, leading to earlier diagnosis. The Welsh health board, Bwrdd Iechyd Cwm Taf, has seen improved patient care due to this approach. The report also mentions that 40% of patients in Merthyr Tydfil have symptoms that are "peri-pryder" (early) for diagnosis in the Cwm Taf area. The passage further explains that family involvement is crucial in patient care and diagnosis, as they are often the first to notice changes in a loved one's health.

England and Pakistan played a series of cricket matches, with England winning the series after leveling it at Old Trafford. England scored 589-8 and 173-1, their second biggest win over Pakistan in terms of runs. Joe Root, promoted to number three, was named man of the match for his outstanding performance, including scoring 254 and an unbeaten 71. England's captain, Alastair Cook, also performed well with scores of 105 and 76 not out. Pakistan, on the other hand, struggled with poor scores and a lack of confidence, managing only 234 in their second innings. Despite this, they showed strong character and determination. The series is expected to be closely contested.

Warren Gatland is the head coach of the British and Irish Lions in New Zealand, with Rob Howley as interim coach. McBryde, the forwards coach, is leading Wales on tours in 2009 and 2013 and will assume head coach responsibilities again for the summer tour. Welsh Rugby Union chief executive Martyn Phillips and union chairman Gareth Davies express optimism about the benefits of Welsh coaches' involvement in the Lions' tour, which they believe will invigorate and inspire the team.
