Over 392,000 cases, 17,100 deaths, and 102,000 recoveries have been reported globally.

Paul Merson and Andros Townsend reignited their dispute after Townsend's England debut, where Merson initially criticized Townsend's call-up and his early exit from Manchester United's squad. Merson later admitted his opinion was wrong after Townsend scored for England. Despite this, Merson continued to criticize Townsend after Tottenham's draw with Burnley. Townsend responded to Merson's comments on Twitter.

Chelsea has made a formal offer for FC Tokyo's 22-year-old forward Yoshinori Muto, who would become the first Japanese player at Chelsea if he accepts. Despite the potential £4 million deal, Muto has not yet decided to join Chelsea. The offer is not related to Chelsea's recent £200 million sponsorship deal with Japanese company Yokohama Rubber. Muto, who has 11 international caps and scored once for Japan, has been praised for his performance with FC Tokyo and is currently on loan at Vitesse Arnhem.

Babies given antibiotics in their first six months are more likely to be overweight as toddlers, according to a large-scale study. The researchers suggest that antibiotics may contribute to the global obesity epidemic by altering gut bacteria and potentially increasing appetite. The study found that by age two, one in five boys and one in ten girls were overweight or obese, with antibiotic use linked to higher odds of being overweight. While the study doesn't prove causation, it highlights the need for careful antibiotic use in infants.

A Buckingham Palace guard slipped and fell on a manhole cover in front of numerous tourists during the Changing of the Guard ceremony. The incident, caught on camera, caused the soldier to drop his rifle and blush as he realized the crowd had witnessed his embarrassing fall. The fall was attributed to metal protectors on the guard's boots. Despite the mishap, the guard quickly regained composure and continued with the ceremony.

A&E networks are remaking the 1977 miniseries "Roots," which originally had over 100 million viewers. The new version, described as "original" and "contemporary," will air in 2016 and draw more from Alex Haley's novel. LeVar Burton, who played Kinte in the original, will co-executive produce. The remake aims to reach both fans of the original and a new generation, amidst current racial tensions in the U.S.

A former royal footman, Christopher Lawler, claims that he was sexually assaulted by palace aides at Clarence House in 1978. He alleges that he was pinned to a chair, groped, and forced into an orgy on his first day. Despite his complaints, he says they were ignored for months before the police were notified. Lawler, now 64, says he was haunted by the incident for years. The police are investigating his claims, and the Royal Household has pledged full cooperation.

An Oregon couple, Jesse and Melissa Meek, announced their pregnancy in a rap video set to the theme song from the '90s sitcom 'The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air.' The video, which has garnered over 1.7 million views, humorously portrays the couple's journey to parenthood. It includes scenes of Melissa realizing she's late and the couple sharing a sonogram of their unborn child. The couple made the video to inform distant friends and family about the pregnancy.

A dress worn by Vivien Leigh as Scarlett O'Hara in the 1939 film "Gone With The Wind" was auctioned for $137,000. The dress, along with over 150 other items from the film, was part of the collection of James Tumblin, who began collecting memorabilia in the 1960s. The dress, originally slate blue-gray, had faded to light gray over time. Other notable items sold included Leigh's straw hat, Clark Gable's Rhett Butler suit, and a black bonnet worn by both Leigh and Olivia De Havilland.

A two-year-old boy fell into a cheetah exhibit at the Cleveland Metroparks Zoo after his parents allegedly dangled him over the edge. The child, unharmed and not attacked by the animals, suffered minor injuries. The incident led to the exhibit's closure and the family facing potential child endangerment charges.

A speed camera in Birmingham, West Midlands, which had been enforcing the 30mph limit, stopped working two years ago along with around 300 other devices in the region. Despite being decommissioned due to outdated technology, this particular camera was recently re-pointed towards a house. The Birmingham City Council is aware and plans to remove it, with no intention to include it in a new digital technology pilot.

Usain Bolt, a six-time Olympic gold medalist, will be part of the Jamaican team at the IAAF/BTC World Relays in the Bahamas, competing on May 2 and 3. Bolt expressed his excitement and readiness to run, highlighting Jamaica's successful relay tradition. The Jamaica Athletics Administrative Association (JAAA) General Secretary, Garth Gayle, anticipates Bolt's performance, referring to him as the world's fastest man. The full Jamaican team list for the competition will be announced soon.

Neymar and Dani Alves showed support for Barcelona's basketball team by attending matches. Neymar led Brazil to victory against Chile, despite facing challenges. Barcelona, with Neymar and Alves, aim for a treble and are currently leading La Liga, with Real Madrid close behind.

Italy is dealing with a surge of migrants from Africa and the Middle East trying to reach Europe. Between Friday and Monday, 8,480 migrants were rescued, with 20 boats in distress reported on Monday alone. Save the Children fears 400 migrants could be missing after a ship carrying 550 people capsized. However, the Italian coast guard cannot confirm this incident. Over 10,000 migrants arrived in Italy in the first three months of 2015, with about 2,000 rescued at sea in April. Most migrants come from West Africa, Somalia, and Syria, using Libya as a transit point. Since the start of the year, at least 480 migrants have died crossing the Mediterranean, often due to bad weather and overcrowded vessels.

Arsene Wenger, the manager of Arsenal, is pleased that Alexis Sanchez chose his team over Liverpool. Sanchez, a 26-year-old Chilean, opted for Arsenal after impressing with his skills in English football. Wenger acknowledged that Liverpool might have used their interest in Sanchez during previous negotiations, but he is content with Sanchez's decision. Wenger also praised Sanchez's quick adaptation to Arsenal and his impact on the team. Meanwhile, Wenger downplayed any potential transfer for Liverpool's Raheem Sterling and commended Brendan Rodgers for developing his team effectively.

Sir Bradley Wiggins, a four-time Olympic champion and 2012 Tour de France winner, plans to break cycling's hour record on June 7 at London's Olympic Velodrome. He aims to surpass the current record of 52.491km, set by Australian Rohan Dennis. Wiggins, who finished his Team Sky career at Paris-Roubaix, will attempt the record in front of a potential 6,000-strong crowd, with tickets available from April 19.

Serena Williams, the twice French Open champion, struggled against Sara Errani in the Fed Cup play-off, revealing her unpreparedness for the claycourt season. Despite her world-class ranking, Williams lost to Errani 4-6 7-6(3) 6-3, and along with Alison Riske, suffered a doubles defeat 6-0 6-3. This resulted in the US being relegated to World Group II. Williams acknowledged the need to adapt her game to clay courts, while the US team, led by captain Mary Joe Fernandez, recognized the necessity to improve and aim for two wins next year to return to the World Group.

River Plate desires to acquire Radamel Falcao, a former Manchester United striker, who previously played eight years with them before moving to Porto in 2009. Despite Falcao's struggles during his loan at United, River Plate's vice president Matias Patanian expressed their aspiration for Falcao and stated that the club is open to his return. Falcao, who joined River Plate at 15, has scored 34 goals in 90 appearances for them.

Ella Henderson, a 19-year-old pop star and X Factor finalist, has become the official face of Batiste's 2015 'Ready For It' campaign, marking her first brand collaboration. The campaign, managed by Crown Talent & Media Group, features Henderson against a blurred city background showcasing various hairstyles. Henderson also appears in a TV advertisement for her latest single, Mirror Man.

Family and friends of Aaron Siler, who was shot and killed by police officer Pablo Torres, are shocked and find a billboard honoring Torres as disrespectful. The billboard, paid for by the Kenosha Professional Police Association, thanks the community for its support. Siler's death occurred after a vehicle and foot pursuit, following an active felony probation and parole warrant. This incident happened 10 days after Torres shot another man, Terry Knight, who was armed with knives. The investigation into Siler's death is ongoing.

Eight Iranian border guards were killed in clashes with militants near the Iran-Pakistan border. The militants, believed to be from Jaish al Adal, crossed into Iran from Pakistan. Iranian officials have requested Pakistan to capture the remaining attackers. Jaish al Adal, a group opposing Iranian influence in Pakistan, claimed responsibility for the attack and previous incidents on Iranian soil. Pakistan condemned the attack and vowed to apprehend the militants if they entered their country.

The passage discusses a political conversation in Japan regarding extraterrestrial life. Defense Minister Gen Nakatani clarified that Japan's Air Self Defense Force has never encountered an unidentified flying object from outer space. Antonio Inoki, a former wrestler and politician, had questioned this in a parliament meeting, leading to Nakatani's response. Inoki himself has claimed to have seen a UFO, but remains unsure about the existence of aliens. This topic has been previously discussed by Japanese politicians, including then-Defense Minister Shigeru Ishiba in 2007.

A passenger, Jin Pai, 35, was hospitalized with severe cuts after a toilet he was squatting on in Hefei Xinqiao International Airport collapsed. He had feared the seat might not be clean, which led him to stand on the toilet rim. The incident, deemed accidental by authorities, resulted in Jin Pai receiving numerous stitches and potentially facing compensation claims due to his initial false statement.

Kevin Rebbie, 56, from Limerick Township, Pennsylvania, was arrested and charged with several offenses, including aggravated indecent assault and invasion of privacy. He allegedly sexually abused a 15-year-old girl over four years, using a hidden camera in her bathroom. The investigation began when the victim discovered the camera in March. Rebbie admitted to filming the victim and other juveniles, with some videos containing explicit content. His preliminary hearing is scheduled for May 1, and he is currently detained on a $500,000 bail.

Yûki Aoyama, a 37-year-old Japanese photographer, created a series of images titled "Daughter and Salaryman" where teenage daughters appear serious while their fathers perform energetic jumps in sharp suits. The daughters, in casual clothing, often smile directly into the camera. The fathers' poses vary, with some appearing slightly pained. The images, taken in front of Japanese landmarks, are intriguing and have garnered online interest.

The passage discusses Kevin Pietersen's return to Surrey cricket and his potential re-entry into the England team. After the dismissal of Paul Downton as England's managing director, attention shifted to the start of the county championship season. Pietersen, who was controversially removed from the England team in 2014, is now with Surrey, aiming to regain his place in the Test team. The team is set to begin their campaign against Glamorgan on April 19.

Romanian club Ceahlaul Piatra Neamt dismissed Brazilian coach Ze Maria for the second time in a week due to poor performance. Despite being reinstated after their loss to FC Botosani, Ze Maria's second term ended after another defeat. He had previously replaced Florin Marin in January and was Ceahlaul's third coach of the season, with Serbian Vanya Radinovic set to take over.

Radamel Falcao, a former Atletico Madrid striker, moved to Manchester United on a season-long loan last summer but has struggled to perform due to a serious knee injury. His former teammate, Nabil Dirar, suggests that Falcao would have been better off staying at Monaco, where he was not happy. Despite this, Manchester United is unlikely to make Falcao's transfer permanent due to the high cost involved.

New Zealand police are seeking public assistance to identify a tall man who robbed a Christchurch dairy, wearing a distinctive cartoon mask and a fluoro orange sweatshirt. The offender, captured on security footage, took about $1,500 in cash and the dairy's till. The incident, which occurred on Saturday, was reported to be particularly frightening due to the mask worn by the robber. Police are urging anyone with information to contact Crimestoppers.

Kaitlyn Granado, a 24-year-old math teacher at MacArthur High School in Texas, was arrested twice for inappropriate relationships with underage students. The first arrest in March 2020 was for having sex with a 15-year-old student in her car on January 18 and 19. The second arrest was for allegedly having a similar relationship with a second 15-year-old student. Granado was suspended from teaching and placed on administrative leave after the first arrest. The second arrest came to light after a school officer learned of a possible relationship between Granado and one of the boys.

A video showing a large crocodile in Puerto Vallarta, Mexico, with a dead dog between its jaws, garnered over half a million views. The crocodile, calmly swimming through a public marina, had the dog in its mouth for an extended period. New Zealander Tim Weston, on holiday with his wife, witnessed the event and described the crocodile's behavior. The dog, owned by a local bike shop, was curious about the crocodile but tragically became its catch. Despite the shocking incident, crocodiles are common in the area, and the video sparked strong reactions from social media users.

Steve Bruce, the manager of Hull City, remains optimistic about avoiding relegation despite a 2-0 loss to Southampton. With six wins so far, he hopes for nine or eight more to secure their position in the Premier League. Hull City's struggles are attributed to several long-term injuries to key players. They face challenging matches against Liverpool, Arsenal, Tottenham, and Manchester United. Additionally, Ronald Koeman, the manager of Southampton, dealt with issues when Sadio Mane attempted to take a penalty during a match against Hull City.

A teacher named Ian Guffick was banned from teaching for at least two years after he admitted to altering and asking students to change their SATs exam answers, which led to the school's results being annulled. Despite claiming he only wanted to make answers more legible, his actions were deemed dishonest but not fraudulent. He was also forced to resign and can appeal the decision.

Anders Lindegaard, a Danish international and goalkeeper for Manchester United, has struggled to secure regular playing time since joining the club in 2010. Despite this, he has found happiness off the pitch, particularly with his wife Misse Beqiri, a Swedish model with Albanian roots. The couple, who have been dating since 2012 and have a son together, got married in a beach wedding in Mauritius. Lindegaard often shares moments with his wife on Instagram, where she has a significant following.

The 13 glowing blue letters that once hung over Yankee Stadium failed to attract any bids at a Sotheby's auction, with the only bid being $260,000 from a Sotheby's employee. The letters, which were expected to fetch between $300,000 and $600,000, were purchased by Yankee Hall of Famer Reggie Jackson in 2008 for an undisclosed amount. The letters, which were 10 feet tall and 10 feet wide, were installed in 1976 and removed in 2008. Additionally, a New York Mets bullpen car from the late 60s was auctioned off and won for $112,500.

Liverpool manager Brendan Rodgers reminded Raheem Sterling and Jordon Ibe about their professional responsibilities after Sterling was caught inhaling nitrous oxide and was later seen with a shisha pipe. Despite these incidents, Rodgers chose not to discipline Sterling or Ibe. He emphasized the importance of understanding the boundaries of a professional athlete's behavior, not just for their own welfare but also due to their responsibilities. Rodgers also discussed Liverpool's journey towards success, acknowledging that they have come close to winning titles and cups but have also experienced losses. He hinted at the possibility of recalling Steven Gerrard for the upcoming FA Cup semi-final against Aston Villa, but did not confirm this.

Mesut Ozil, an Arsenal player, returned from an international break in London and posted a picture of him relaxing with his dog. After missing Arsenal's previous game due to illness, Ozil is expected to start against Liverpool. He recently impressed in a Euro 2016 qualifier against Georgia, contributing four assists and three goals since January. Ozil also mentioned adapting well to English football, despite its demanding schedule.

Barcelona club president Josep Maria Bartomeu is pleased with Luis Enrique's performance as the team's manager. Despite speculation, Bartomeu has no plans to replace Enrique, who has only been in charge for a year. Enrique is currently under contract until 2016. The team is currently six games away from winning the La Liga title, and they recently defeated Valencia with goals from Luis Suarez and Lionel Messi.

Jordan Henderson, a midfielder for Liverpool, has agreed to a new long-term contract worth approximately £100,000 per week, running until 2020. This decision came after discussions between Henderson's advisors and Liverpool, following the club's FA Cup loss. Henderson, 24, is the third player in Brendan Rodgers' squad to secure a contract extension, following Daniel Sturridge and Philippe Coutinho. His excellent performance this season, including 13 assists and seven goals, has made him a potential candidate for the club captain role. Additionally, Liverpool's Chief Executive expects Raheem Sterling to remain with the club for a long time, despite his contract rejection.

Filipe Luis, a player for Chelsea, expresses his desire to remain with the club until the end of his contract, despite Atletico Madrid's interest in re-signing him. He has faced challenges establishing himself in the left back position at Chelsea. Meanwhile, Chelsea's manager, Jose Mourinho, emphasizes the need for the team to stay focused and win every match. Filipe Luis is now focused on the Premier League, particularly as Brazil faces France and Chile in upcoming friendlies.

Nathan Hughes, a forward for Wasps, had his three-match ban for accidentally knocking out George North overturned on appeal. Initially suspended for being'reckless' after his knee collided with North's head during a try-scoring incident on March 27, Hughes was shown a red card. Despite no intent, he received a further sanction. However, the appeal, supported by criticism and defense from various parties, was successful. The panel concluded there was no foul play as the incident was accidental.

A Seattle native named Tim Durkan captured aerial images of a red sunset in Washington due to smoke from wildfires in Siberia. The fires, believed to have been caused by strong winds, destroyed villages and spread across the region. The smoke traveled across the Pacific Ocean, affecting Oregon, Washington, and British Columbia. The intense red sunset was caused by smoke particles filtering out shorter wavelength colors, allowing red and orange to pass through unfiltered. As the smoke dissipates, the sunsets will lose their reddish hue and air quality will improve.

Becky Schoenig's 2015 Ford Fusion was stolen from her driveway in Missouri, but was later returned with modifications including red rims and detailing. Instead of being upset, Schoenig thanked the thieves on Facebook and created a smoothie to honor the person who found her car.

Manchester City players risk losing £500,000 each if they don't qualify for the Champions League, due to incentivized contracts aimed at maintaining financial fairplay. Following a defeat in the Manchester derby, their season has seen decline, with potential losses for key players like Sergio Aguero, David Silva, Joe Hart, and Yaya Toure. City's poor performance, including seven losses and exits from FA Cup and Champions League, has led to criticism from manager Manuel Pellegrini. The team's failure to secure a top-four Premier League finish could result in a significant financial impact, with around £12 million at stake.

In a'mini-derby' match between United's Under 18s and City, United won 1-0. The game featured 13 English players, with 10 from Manchester. Callum Gribbin scored the winning goal for United with a free-kick. The match was played at Moss Lane, with no ticket prices and a crowd of around 1,000. Despite the loss, City's performance showcased potential talents deserving of first-team opportunities.

England goalkeeper Joe Hart, who recently earned his 50th cap, praised fellow goalkeeper Gianluigi Buffon as a "legend of the game" for his 147th cap. Hart, 10 years younger than Buffon, admires Buffon's skill and dedication, especially at the age of 37. Despite having fewer caps himself, Hart aspires to continue his career, both for his club and country.

Chipotle, a fast-casual Mexican restaurant, plans to enter the $70 billion food delivery market by collaborating with the Postmates app for online and mobile orders in 67 cities. The service will include a nine percent charge, with delivery fees starting at $5. Chipotle previously declined similar partnerships but has now partnered with Postmates. This move aligns with other franchises like Starbucks and Taco Bell also venturing into food delivery services.

The parents of Martin Richard, the youngest victim of the 2013 Boston Marathon bombings, are pleading against the death penalty for Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, the convicted bomber. They argue that the death penalty would prolong their suffering and that they would support its removal in exchange for Tsarnaev spending his life in prison without appeal rights. The family emphasizes their personal stance and hopes for a future free from the painful reminder of the tragedy.

A mystery billionaire purchased a Boeing 747 for £400 million, converting it into a luxury home with multiple rooms including bedrooms, lounges, and a restaurant. The plane, typically for 600 passengers, is now designed for the owner and their guests, featuring a large dining room, aeroloft sleeping area, and various other opulent spaces.

SpaceX successfully launched an uncrewed Dragon cargo spacecraft to the International Space Station aboard a Falcon 9 rocket. However, the rocket failed to land safely on a floating barge, tipping over after a previous attempt in January. The Dragon will deliver supplies to the space station, including an espresso maker, and return over 3,000 pounds of cargo to Earth. This mission is the sixth for SpaceX and the second attempt for this specific mission.

Priscilla Presley will witness the first wedding at the newly established Elvis Presley's Graceland Wedding Chapel in Las Vegas. The winning couple, chosen through a contest initiated by NBC's Today show, will marry on April 23rd at the Westgate Hotel. The couple will also receive a free wedding reception, hotel suite, airfare, and concert tickets. Elvis Presley's former wife, Priscilla, emphasized the seriousness of the chapel, denying any impersonators. Couples must submit a video and explanation to be considered for the prize.

Liverpool vice-captain Jordan Henderson believes his team can overtake Manchester City in the Premier League, despite being four points behind. Henderson and goalkeeper Simon Mignolet both played their 47th game of the season, equalling a record in the top five European leagues. Liverpool recently found winning form after disappointing performances and results. In their match against Newcastle, Raheem Sterling scored first, and Joe Allen scored his first Anfield goal, securing a 2-0 win. Newcastle thought they deserved a penalty for a foul by Dejan Lovren on Ayoze Perez.

Roma ended a four-month winless streak with a victory over Napoli in Serie A, moving provisionally four points ahead of Lazio. Miralem Pjanic scored in the 25th minute after a counter-attack, and goalkeeper Morgan de Sanctis saved numerous shots in the second half. Despite Napoli's winless streak extending to five matches, they managed to secure a win. Security measures were heightened due to a previous shooting incident involving a Roma fan.

Doncaster Rovers had a lackluster season, resulting in a mid-table League One position. Their match against Fleetwood Town ended in a 0-0 draw, which was not particularly exciting. Due to the short duration of the highlights video, it only included the kickoff, a goal kick, and the final whistle.

Roland Giroux massages and interacts with his blood parrot cichlid daily, including stroking and feeding it by hand. The fish, initially bullied by two others in its tank, became more sociable and enjoyed being stroked. Giroux noticed the fish's frustration if not played with daily. The blood parrot cichlid, a hybrid bred in Taiwan, is now accustomed to human interaction.

Ben Stokes, known for his fiery character in the England cricket team, has a history of aggression, exemplified by breaking his wrist punching a locker. Despite a year of ups and downs, Stokes has returned to the team and is expected to contribute with his aggression. However, he needs careful management to avoid being pigeonholed and to ensure his natural exuberance does not hinder the team's performance. England aims to maximize Stokes' potential while also considering the roles of other players like Adil Rashid and Chris Jordan.

Wales' Euro 2016 qualifier against Belgium, held at the Cardiff City Stadium, was a sell-out event with 33,000 attendees. Both teams, Belgium and Wales, have 11 points from five games, but Belgium leads due to a better goal difference. Wales' victory over Israel increased their chances of qualifying for the Euro 2016 finals, with the team expressing a preference for the Cardiff City Stadium over the Millennium Stadium.

England's under-17 team, led by coach John Peacock, is set to compete in the UEFA European Championship in Bulgaria. The defending champions, with a flawless qualifying record, are in Group D with Holland, Italy, and Ireland. The squad includes players from various Premier League clubs, with Chelsea's Jay Dasilva and Ike Ugbo, Arsenal's Chris Willock and Stephy Mavididi, and Liverpool's Herbie Kane and Trent Arnold among the notable names. The team will kick off against Italy on May 7, followed by matches against Holland and Ireland.

Manchester City aims to acquire 14-year-old Anderlecht player Evangelos Patoulidis, considered a top talent. Patoulidis previously declined Barcelona's offer to continue his education. Manchester City, under Manuel Pellegrini, is interested in him to strengthen their future prospects.

A 33-year-old Mexican transgender escort, Vanessa Santillan, was found murdered in a £400,000 flat in Fulham, London. Her body showed severe injuries to the head and neck. A 23-year-old man was arrested in connection with her death but has been released on bail. Scotland Yard is investigating and urges anyone who had contact with Santillan before her death to come forward. Detective Chief Inspector Rebecca Reeves emphasized the need for information from anyone who knew Santillan in London.

A woman named Dawn, who suffered seven miscarriages, discovered her friend Jamie had stolen £207 meant for her unborn child's gravestone. Jamie, a convicted burglar, was caught lying during a lie detector test on The Jeremy Kyle show. Devastated, Dawn expressed feeling betrayed and horrible, as the money was intended as a loving gesture for her lost child.

ISIS released more than 200 Yazidis, a minority group persecuted for their unique religious beliefs, in a coordinated effort with Arab tribal leaders. The majority of those released were women and children, with some being ill or elderly. This release followed previous instances where ISIS freed Yazidis, particularly children and the elderly. The group's actions have led to significant humanitarian crises, including the trapping of Yazidis in mountains without resources and the enslavement of female captives.

Harry Kane, a Tottenham and England player, is nominated for both PFA Player and Young Player of the Year awards. He features in a new animation highlighting his goals and celebrations, including a notable strike against Chelsea. The video, released before the awards ceremony, adds to speculation about him winning the PFA Player of the Year award.

Jamie Carragher supports Brendan Rodgers as Liverpool's manager despite the team's third consecutive trophy-less season and potential fourth-place finish. Carragher believes Rodgers' future shouldn't be determined by one game and emphasizes the importance of the right signings. He also highlights Rodgers' responsibility to improve the team and his commitment to community work in Merseyside.

Four-year-old James Hayward had his plastic nerf gun confiscated at East Midlands Airport due to security concerns. His parents, Phil and Hazel, were late for their flight and had to leave the toy behind. Upon returning from their holiday, James received a new toy gun purchased from eBay. The airport apologized for the inconvenience, citing government regulations that prohibit items resembling prohibited items, such as certain types of toy guns.

A 31-year-old man, identifying as 'Rich', from Humpty Doo, Northern Territory, posted an advertisement on Gumtree seeking a girlfriend or wife. He described his dream partner as someone who loves pets, is non-drinking, non-smoking, and fit. The successful candidate should be reliable, honest, loyal, good around the house, skilled with their hands, a good cook, and great in bed. Additionally, she should be willing to enjoy the outdoors and act like a princess when needed. Rich, who is athletic, heavily tattooed, and has a well-endowed figure, is also successful, owns property, and makes a good income. He is willing to spend money on his partner and promises to consider all reasonable offers.

Greg Dyke, chair of the Football Association, is supported by five former England managers in his bid to implement significant changes. These include increasing the minimum number of home-grown players in club squads from eight to 12 and altering the definition of 'home-grown' to mean training in England for three years before turning 18. The managers warn that rejecting these proposals could hinder England's progress and ability to win the World Cup. They also highlight the limited number of Premier League players eligible for England selection and the need for more opportunities for young talents like Harry Kane, Raheem Sterling, and Ross Barkley.

Demelza Poldark, played by Eleanor Tomlinson, is now eight months pregnant and is set to give birth in the show's next episode. The pregnancy timeline is fast-paced, with the announcement in the previous episode and the birth occurring within minutes in the upcoming one. Fans have noticed the quick progression of Demelza's relationship with Ross Poldark, who is played by Aidan Turner.

Leicester's manager, Nigel Pearson, advises his team to concentrate on their own performance and not be distracted by their relegation rivals. Despite being three points from safety and bottom of the table, Leicester's recent 3-2 win has given them a chance to survive in the Premier League. Pearson emphasizes that their future depends on their own efforts and they must ensure their remaining games align with their goals.

A North Pacific gray whale named Varvara, meaning "Barbara," completed the longest mammal migration ever recorded, swimming nearly 14,000 miles from Russia's Sakhalin Island to Baja, Mexico. This journey surpassed the previous Guinness World Record held by a humpback whale. Varvara's trip revealed surprising information about eastern gray whales, as she visited three major breeding areas during her journey. This suggests that some western gray whales might actually be eastern grays, potentially impacting the estimated population of 150 western gray whales.

Residents on Hokkaido Island, Japan, discovered a new stretch of land along the Shiretoko Peninsula near Rausu, measuring roughly 1,000-1,640ft long and 100ft wide. The land, which emerged as high as 50ft above sea level, is believed to be the result of a landslide caused by melting ice and snow. The sudden appearance of the landmass surprised locals, who reported no sounds or tremors beforehand. Authorities expect the landmass not to expand further.

Gregory van der Wiel, a player for Paris Saint-Germain, has denied any plans to leave the club in the summer. Despite a recent disagreement with manager Laurent Blanc over his exclusion from a Champions League match, van der Wiel expressed his happiness and love for PSG, the city, and his teammates. He stated there was no reason for him to leave and expressed his desire to sign a new contract. The possibility of a transfer to Barcelona's Dani Alves remains uncertain.

Carlos Tevez, a former Manchester City striker, reportedly wants to leave Juventus to return to his former club Boca Juniors in Argentina. Despite his contract with Juventus not expiring until 2016, Tevez reportedly wishes to terminate it this summer. Boca Juniors is close to finalizing a deal for Tevez, but Juventus must first be notified of the contract termination. Tevez has scored 17 goals this season and is a key player for Juventus, but they are already considering potential replacements. Tevez has always intended to finish his career at Boca Juniors, and his move would not affect his future with the Argentina national team.

Pep Guardiola, Bayern Munich manager, ripped a hole in his trousers during a 6-1 Champions League victory against Porto. The incident occurred amidst Bayern's impressive performance, which included goals from multiple players and secured their place in the semi-finals. Guardiola humorously mentioned he would need new trousers for the next match.

Ten people, including four children, were involved in a multi-vehicle crash on the Brisbane Valley Highway near Fernvale. Three vehicles collided, resulting in injuries such as chest and shoulder pain, arm injuries, and abdominal pain. Three patients were airlifted to the Princess Alexandra Hospital in Brisbane, while others were taken to Ipswich Hospital. The highway was temporarily closed for diversions.

Arsenal's Mesut Ozil received a new Apple Watch, comparing it to Knight Rider's character Michael Knight. Ozil, who scored four goals in 25 matches this season, is expected to play against Chelsea in a Premier League match. Arsenal trails Chelsea by 10 points with six games left. Jack Wilshere, who was on the bench in Arsenal's FA Cup semi-final win, is seen as the future of the club, but his fitness is a concern due to past injuries.

Mark Clattenburg, a referee with a history of controversy, will officiate the Manchester derby between United and City. Despite sending off three players from United and City this season, Clattenburg has only issued two red cards in the Premier League this season. He will be assisted by Simon Beck and Jake Collin, with Jonathan Moss as the fourth official.

Outspoken MP Bob Katter risked a race row by accusing the Queensland Government of treating Billy Gordon, an embattled MP, as a 'little black puppet on a string'. Katter claimed Gordon would resign after being accused of domestic violence and hiding his criminal past. This assumption, according to Katter, was never questioned in federal cases. Katter, who has faced racist attitudes himself, defended his controversial terminology, stating it reflected his personal experiences. Despite criticism on social media, Katter stood by his statement, asserting Gordon would not become a puppet for the government.

Dayna Dobias, a 19-year-old Illinois teenager with cerebral palsy, uses dance and video creation to challenge stereotypes and inspire others. Despite facing bullying and being defined by her disability, Dayna aims to show that she is just like everyone else. She has produced several videos, including one to Taylor Swift's song, and now engages in motivational speaking at local schools.

Orlando City, a team with a large Latin-American fanbase, has shown interest in Mexico international Javier Hernandez, who is currently struggling at Real Madrid. Despite this, eight European clubs, including Manchester United, are also keen on Hernandez. Manchester United has also revised its contract offer to 19-year-old Andreas Pereira, who has received interest from several European clubs.

A group of at least three individuals set a car on fire at a South Los Angeles gas station early Saturday morning. The driver, pumping gas at 12:15am, claimed the suspects attempted to carjack him. The suspects covered the white Dodge Charger with gasoline and ignited it while two passengers were inside. The car was completely destroyed, but no one was hurt. The incident is being investigated as arson by the Los Angeles County Fire Department, with surveillance footage aiding the investigation.

A southern Iowa chiropractor, Charles Manuel, surrendered his license after admitting to exchanging sex for services and performing exorcisms on patients. Despite these misdeeds, he received perfect patient satisfaction ratings on HealthGrades.com. Manuel is now barred from practicing in the state for at least 10 years and must prove the revocation circumstances no longer exist.

The US is complaining to Russia about a recent incident where a Russian SU-27 intercepted a US reconnaissance plane, the RC-135U, in an "unsafe and unprofessional manner" over the Baltic Sea. The US crew perceived the Russian pilot's aggressive maneuvers and high speed as dangerous. This incident is not the first of its kind, as a similar event occurred a year prior. The US plans to address the issue through diplomatic channels.

An FBI sniper rifle was stolen from a Salt Lake City hotel parking lot, just days before President Obama's visit. The rifle, secured in a hard case with padlocks and chains, was taken by breaking the car window and using a rope to free the case. The agent's gear bag, backpack, clothing, and tools were also stolen. Despite the theft, the rifle's serial number was entered into the National Crime Information Computer. The Secret Service was notified about the stolen rifle prior to the president's visit, but did not comment on any increased security measures.

Luigi Costa, 71 and suffering from dementia and alcohol abuse, allegedly killed his neighbor Terrence Freebody in 2012. Forensic psychiatrist Professor Paul Mullen stated that Costa's mood fluctuated and his mental state was compromised due to dementia and alcohol. The jury may find Costa not guilty if his unstable mindset during the attack is proven.

Everton manager Roberto Martinez defended Ross Barkley's decision to take a penalty in a 1-0 win against Burnley, despite Leighton Baines being the usual choice. Barkley, stepping in for the first time, missed the shot, but it didn't affect the game's outcome as Mirallas later scored the only goal. Martinez stated that Barkley had the right to request penalty duties and expressed his satisfaction with players taking control in crucial moments.

Two passengers on the Holland America Line's ship, the ms Ryndam, died in a murder-suicide in Puerto Rico. The incident occurred in their stateroom, and the FBI was notified. The ship was en route from Tampa, Florida to San Juan, Puerto Rico on a 14-day cruise. The discovery was made by the cleaning staff after they knocked on the cabin door.

Patrick Kluivert, former Holland forward and assistant coach, led Curacao to the second qualifying round in the 2018 World Cup. The team advanced after a 4-3 aggregate win against Montserrat and a 2-1 victory in Willemstad. Kluivert, who is of Curacao descent, previously assisted Louis van Gaal at the 2014 World Cup and was part of the 1998 World Cup losing semi-final team.

Esteban Cambiasso, a former player for Inter Milan and Real Madrid, believes that helping Leicester City avoid relegation from the Premier League would be as rewarding as winning any major European trophy. Despite Leicester's poor performance, with only eight games left in the season, Cambiasso remains optimistic about their chances. He emphasizes the importance of this objective and expresses his happiness with his family and the team's situation. Cambiasso has quickly become a key player for Leicester and could potentially stay beyond his current one-year deal.

A 23-year-old mother named Gemma, who has two children under five, risks losing contact with them due to her excessive drinking, partying, and alleged theft. Gemma handed her children over to her mother, Debbie, at four months old, but Debbie is now considering banning Gemma from their lives because she suspects her of stealing, including an iPad sold to fund her lifestyle. Debbie, who has been raising the children since social services threatened to remove them, claims Gemma's behavior has been problematic since she was 13.

During a match between Chelsea and Manchester United, Chelsea captain John Terry made a strong challenge on United's Radamel Falcao, causing a foul that led to Eden Hazard scoring a goal. Sky Sports pundits agreed that Terry's rough tackle on Falcao should have resulted in play being stopped.

Lady Antebellum's tour bus caught fire on a Texas freeway due to a blown-out rear tire, but everyone on board was safely evacuated. The incident was captured on video by Michael Barnett, who stopped filming upon realizing the bus belonged to the country band. Hillary Scott posted a photo of the charred bus on Instagram, expressing gratitude for everyone's safety. The band's two other members were not on the bus during the incident.

Dr. Adrian Quarterman, a Scottish scientist, proposes using space lasers to power homes by converting sunlight into laser light via satellites equipped with mirrors. This energy, generated using semi-conductors, could potentially enhance solar power in Scotland or provide immediate power restoration in disaster-stricken areas. While the lasers are not as powerful as depicted in films, Dr. Quarterman has not dismissed the possibility of misuse, raising concerns about control. This concept differs from a Tokyo research team's proposal to use lasers on the ISS to eliminate space debris, which would not be potent enough for weaponization.

Stephen Munden, a 54-year-old man with learning difficulties and an obsession with young girls, went missing after leaving a hospital near Hook, Hampshire. He was last seen on Tuesday evening and had been detained under the Mental Health Act for sexually touching a three-year-old girl. Munden, who was convicted of sexual offences and possessing indecent images of children, is described as heavyset with dark hair. Officers are conducting a manhunt for him, emphasizing the urgency due to his hospital order and previous convictions.

V. Stiviano, Donald Sterling's former female companion, was ordered by a Los Angeles judge to pay back over $2.6 million in gifts. These gifts included luxury cars and items like an Easter bunny costume and a lace thong. Sterling's racist remarks and illicit relationship with Stiviano led to his NBA team's termination and a significant financial loss for Stiviano.

Thierry Henry criticized Arsenal's transfer dealings and urged them to buy four top players: a goalkeeper, centre back, defensive midfielder, and a high-quality striker. He questioned Arsenal's chances of winning the Premier League title with Olivier Giroud as their first choice striker, despite Giroud's 14 league goals this season. Henry emphasized the need for Arsenal to sign players of similar calibre to those acquired by Chelsea, such as Thibaut Courtois, Nemanja Matic, Cesc Fabregas, and Diego Costa.

A young woman, subjected to years of abuse by Bega Cheese boss Maurice Van Ryn, testified in court about the severe impact it had on her life. Van Ryn, who pleaded guilty to 12 sex offences including persistent sexual abuse of a child, did not acknowledge the young woman during the proceedings. The victim expressed fear for her future relationships and struggled to understand why she was targeted. She also revealed that she had attempted suicide and had kept the abuse a secret until she learned of Van Ryn's arrest.

Serge Gnabry, a 19-year-old midfielder for Arsenal, is recovering well from a serious knee injury that has kept him out of play for over a year. He recently played 90 minutes for Arsenal's Under-21s against Reading, marking his return to action. Gnabry had previously impressed in the previous season before his progress was halted due to the injury.

A 23-year-old accountant named Jacob Phillips tragically fell to his death after running from a taxi to avoid paying the fare. The incident occurred in South Wales when Phillips, along with friends, attempted to evade the fare by leaping out of the taxi. The driver, unable to see in the dark, stopped the cab and chased after them. Phillips, disoriented, leapt over a fence and fell down a 70ft cliff. The coroner recorded an accidental death, noting that Phillips likely didn't realize the danger he was in.

Thousands of holidaymakers affected by last summer's passport delay fiasco received no compensation, despite the passport agency making a £42 million profit during the crisis. Only 2,191 compensation applications were approved, with an average payout of £92.68. The agency's managers received up to £3,500 in bonuses, and ministers rejected a demand for blanket refunds, citing precedent concerns.

A time-warp home from the 1930s, located in Horfield, Bristol, is up for sale. The untouched property, which has remained in its original state for over 80 years, features stained-glass windows, oil-fired central heating, and retro food jars. The house includes the original bathroom and kitchen, wood-panelled hallway, and vintage cupboards. Despite some upgrades like double glazing, the property's unique features and potential renovation costs have led to a guide price of £200,000 to £250,000. The house will be auctioned on April 30 at the County Ground in Bristol.

Vietnam, officially the Socialist Republic of Vietnam, is the easternmost country on the Indochina Peninsula in Southeast Asia, with an estimated population of 92.7 million. It is the 14th most populous country globally and the ninth in Asia. Vietnam shares borders with China, Laos, Cambodia, Thailand, the Philippines, Malaysia, and Indonesia. Since 2000, Vietnam has experienced high economic growth rates, ranking as the highest Global Growth Generators Index among 11 major economies in 2011. It is one of the world's four remaining one-party socialist states officially espousing communism.
Dreamer is a 2005 American sports drama film, written and directed by John Gatins, marking his directorial debut.

Bhagat Singh was a charismatic Indian socialist revolutionary, known for his dramatic acts of violence against the British in India. He was executed at the young age of 23, which led to his status as a folk hero in the Indian independence movement.
Aparshakti Khurana debuted in Bollywood with Aamir Khan's film "Dangal" in 2016. "Dangal" is a Hindi-language biographical sports drama directed by Nitesh Tiwari.

James VI and I, ruling Scotland as James VI from 1567 and England and Ireland as James I from 1603 until his death in 1625, faced challenges with Parliament during his English reign. He advocated for a unified parliament for England and Scotland.

Danielle Cormack, born on December 26, 1970, is a New Zealand actress known for her roles in Shortland Street, Xena: Warrior Princess, The Cult, Legend of the Seeker, Separation City, Rake, and Underbelly: Razor. She gained prominence for portraying Bea Smith in the Foxtel prison drama Wentworth for four years until 2016.
Rob Sheridan, born on October 11, 1979, is an American graphic designer, director, and photographer renowned for his significant contributions to the band Nine Inch Nails.

David Spade starred in films like Tommy Boy, Black Sheep, Joe Dirt, and Joe Dirt 2: Beautiful Loser, among others. He also co-wrote Joe Dirt 2: Beautiful Loser, which was directed by Fred Wolf and released in 2015.
Angela Evelyn Bassett, born on August 16, 1958, is an American actress.

Artpop is Lady Gaga's album that received mixed reviews but was commercially successful, debuting at number one in the U.S. with 258,000 copies sold in the first week. It became her second consecutive U.S. number-one record and sold 757,000 copies overall. The album was the ninth best seller of 2013, with 2.3 million copies sold worldwide.
John Frusciante's fifth and final album with the Chili Peppers, Stadium Arcadium, was released in 2006. This album was also the last to feature guitarist John Frusciante, who left the band in 2009.

Margaret Thatcher, as Prime Minister, implemented policies termed Thatcherism. She remains a controversial figure, praised as one of Britain's greatest and most influential politicians, despite ongoing debates over Thatcherism.

Michael Andrew "Duff" McKagan is an American musician, singer, songwriter, and author. He has also made a name for himself as a writer, contributing weekly columns to SeattleWeekly.com, Playboy.com, and ESPN.com.
Tom Baker, an English actor, has also worked as a narrator for commercials, video games, audiobooks, and television series.

Valencia, officially València, is the capital of the autonomous community of Valencia in Spain. It is the country's third largest city after Madrid and Barcelona, with around 800,000 inhabitants in its administrative center. Valencia is also the third largest metropolitan area in Spain, with a population ranging from 1.7 to 2.5 million. The Valencian Community, or the Valencian Country, is an autonomous community of Spain, with Valencia as its homonymous capital city and metropolitan area.
Buffy Summers was played by Kristy Swanson in a film and later by Sarah Michelle Gellar in the television series.
The series "Make It or Break It" concluded after three seasons, with the final season announced on April 26, 2012. The series finale aired on May 14, 2012.

Speech recognition is a sub-field of computational linguistics that enables computers to recognize and translate spoken language into text. It combines knowledge from linguistics, computer science, and electrical engineering. Applications include voice user interfaces, call routing, home automation, search, data entry, document preparation, speech-to-text processing, and aircraft systems. The field has seen significant advancements due to the adoption of deep learning methods by major industry players like Google, Microsoft, IBM, and others.
Richard Alf, an American businessman and former comic book store owner, co-founded the San Diego Comic-Con International in 1970. He also served as its chairman.
Fist of Legend is a remake of the 1972 film Fist of Fury, starring Bruce Lee as the main character.

Rory McIlroy, tied with Van Zyl of South Africa and Kiradech Aphibarnrat of Thailand, carded a third consecutive five under-par 67. Despite a three-putt on the third and 10th holes, he made a birdie on the 11th and an eagle on the 13th. McIlroy aims for his first title since May and is targeting a third Race to Dubai title in four years. He leads England's Danny Willett by 271 points with three events remaining.

Sheikh Ali Salman emphasized the necessity of the government's willingness to provide concrete solutions for meaningful national dialogue. Crown Prince Salman al-Khalifa, viewed as a reformist, is seen as a potential partner for dialogue with opposition groups. However, hardliners within the government, led by unelected Prime Minister Sheikh Khalifa bin Salman al-Khalifa, oppose dialogue, fearing it will encourage further demands from distrusted opposition leaders. Despite this, Sheikh Salman insists on dialogue and negotiations, expressing hope for US Secretary of State John Kerry to push for clearer human rights policies. He also criticizes the UK for not publicly pressuring Bahrain to end violence and human rights abuses. Al-Wefaq leader reiterates the call for peaceful demonstrations and the release of imprisoned opposition leaders, stating their involvement is crucial for successful dialogue.

Christopher Hogwood, a renowned figure in the early-music movement, passed away at his Cambridge home after a prolonged illness. He was the founder of the Academy of Ancient Music (AAM) and directed it for three decades, producing over 200 CDs. Hogwood's influential recordings include the 1980 Handel's Messiah. He studied at Cambridge University and held various prestigious positions, including artistic director of the King's Lynn Festival and Boston's Handel and Haydn Society. He was also a tutor at Harvard University and honorary professor at the University of Cambridge and Cornell University. His death is mourned by many, with his legacy in historically informed music being highly regarded.

The number of homicide victims in Scotland decreased to 57 for the year ending March 2016, the lowest in a decade. One case from the previous year remained unsolved. Despite this decline, sexual crimes are at a 45-year high, and violent crimes like attempted murder and serious assault increased by 27%. Sharp instruments, mainly knives, were used in 51% of homicides. Efforts to reduce violent crime continue, with a focus on education, enforcement, and addressing irresponsible attitudes towards alcohol misuse and violence.

The Cherries lost 2-1 to Sunderland in the Premier League, marking the first loss for Sunderland against Bournemouth this season. Despite having six goals against Hull before these games, Bournemouth failed to score due to missed opportunities and a lack of confidence. Sunderland's victory was aided by goals from Victor Anichebe and Jermain Defoe, with Bournemouth unable to equalize even with a man down after Steven Pienaar's dismissal.

Mr Abbott, the Australian leader, asserts that halting boats is the only way to prevent deaths at sea. Australia detains migrants at sea and resettles them offshore, a policy the New York Times labels "brutal" and "inhumane". Despite criticism, Abbott defends his stance, comparing IS militants' boasting of their evil to the Nazis' shame. Australian Jewish groups condemn Abbott's comments, stating a significant difference between IS terrorism and Nazi genocide.

Washington blamed Russia and the Syrian government for intensifying attacks against civilians in Aleppo, Syria. The US suspended talks and bilateral channels with Russia due to Russia's alleged failure to prevent bombings and ensure adherence to agreements. Russia denied involvement in a deadly aid convoy strike and criticized the US for not fulfilling key conditions of the agreement and for failing to separate jihadist groups from the moderate opposition.

Downing Street supports a Policy Exchange report suggesting selling high-value vacant homes could raise £4.5bn annually. This funding could build 80,000-170,000 social homes, potentially reducing the 1.8 million on waiting lists by half a million. Critics, including Labour, argue this policy would displace low-income families and exacerbate segregation. Policy Exchange defines expensive social housing as worth more than the average property in each region, which accounts for 21.8% of the total social housing stock in the UK.

Gareth Colfer-Williams, 25, died in Swansea amidst a measles epidemic, with 942 cases reported. Despite laboratory confirmation of measles, the cause of death remains undetermined. An inquest is set for Tuesday to conduct further tests. Mr. Colfer-Williams had been treated for asthma and developed a rash before his death. His family was unaware of how he contracted measles, as no close relatives had the disease, and his daughter was vaccinated.
Vincent Hudson, 54, charged with a 2001 historical offence involving a boy under 16 in Cumbria. He is set to appear in court later.

Neil Aspin's team, Guiseley, and Adam Lockwood's team, Gateshead, ended the match in a draw, with both teams scoring once. The game saw several key events, including Guiseley taking an early lead, Gateshead's defender blocking a shot, and both teams making substitutions. The match concluded with Guiseley and Gateshead each having one goal.

Bristol Sport Ltd, the owner of a football club, plans to replace two stands to increase stadium capacity. This plan is an alternative to building a new stadium at Ashton Vale, which has been delayed due to an application for a town green. The club's majority shareholder, Steve Lansdown, confirmed the club would start work after signing a section 106 agreement, with the project potentially beginning in May if no judicial review occurs.

Cuadrilla halted fracking operations in Lancashire, UK after a 1.5 magnitude tremor, the second in two months. The British Geological Survey (BGS) is analyzing data to determine if operations should resume. Fracking, or "hydraulic fracturing," involves releasing gas by fracturing shale rocks underground. Cuadrilla's CEO emphasized their commitment to safety and consultation with authorities. The BGS stated that any process injecting pressurized water into rocks could cause earthquakes, and they are monitoring fracking as a precaution. Two small earthquakes have occurred since fracking began in March. The latest tremor was felt in Poulton-le-Fylde and had a similar location and mechanism to a previous event.

Angus Carpenter, a Liverpool busker, denied three counts of fraud but was found guilty of one count related to a Hillsborough Justice Campaign banner he displayed while busking in 2015. He was cleared of two other counts and had permission from the charity's chairman to use the banner as a tribute, not for fundraising. Carpenter, known for his performances in the city centre, will be sentenced in January.

In the match, Ipswich Town secured a 3-0 victory over Queens Park Rangers. Grant Ward's shot was saved by Alex Smithies, but Luke Varney later rolled the ball into an empty net after a miscue by Smithies. Tom Lawrence scored the final goal for Ipswich, capitalizing on a long-range shot by Cole Skuse. Despite Ipswich's struggles in attack, they managed to overcome Rangers' defensive efforts. Rangers' keeper Smithies had a challenging game, with several costly errors, including misjudging a clearance and conceding a goal. Ipswich's manager, Mick McCarthy, acknowledged the team's lack of confidence but praised their performance in securing the win.

Wells, 23, performed impressively in the T20 Blast last season, scoring 373 runs with a strike rate of 138.66. He expressed excitement about the club's direction and the elite performance environment created by the coaches.

The Reds, currently fifth in National Two South, secured a second consecutive win against Chinnor with a score of 29-12. This victory was attributed to the efforts of players Tommy Phillips, Ben Priddey, and Craig Williams, who led the team with over 70 tackles. Despite the win, the coach, Churcher, emphasized the need for improvement and building on the previous week's performance, as the team faces seven upcoming matches against lower-ranked teams and league leaders Old Elthamians.

Nazrul, also known as Nazu, a 28-year-old Bangladeshi citizen, is alleged to be the man who raped a 74-year-old nun in India. He was arrested at a Kolkata railway station after police acted on a tip that he was returning to the city. This arrest is part of the investigation into a crime that has now resulted in six arrests, with eight suspects identified, two of whom remain untraced. The police claim that all five previously arrested individuals named Nazrul as the rapist. The incident also involved theft and ransacking of a convent school building.

The passage discusses an interactive video featuring Robert Opie, founder of the Museum of Brands, Packaging and Advertising in London. The video highlights factors influencing changes in UK consumer purchases, such as the introduction of domestic freezers, washing powder, and cheaper imports. It also examines shifts in ownership and ranking of major UK brands. A non-interactive version of the video is available for those using older browsers. Additional information can be found through provided links.

A woman in Stranraer lost money to a scammer pretending to be from BT technical support, who gained remote access to her computer. This incident occurred seven days after a similar scam in Sandyhills. Authorities warn people to be cautious of such cold calls and not to share banking details over the phone.

Duffy, a 37-year-old Scotland assistant coach, has signed a one-year contract with Featherstone to lead them in their final league game against Toulouse. He previously played for Leigh, Widnes, and Salford, and was replaced by his former assistant at Swinton. The Featherstone chairman praised Duffy's potential impact on the team.

A rider suffered head injuries and hypothermia after an incident at Sker Beach near Porthcawl. The RNLI crew, including a medic and coastguard, along with a rescue helicopter, attended the scene at 12:50 GMT on Sunday. The injured rider was then taken to Cardiff's University Hospital of Wales.

At a UN conference in Geneva, a decision was made to allocate a portion of the radio spectrum for a global flight tracking system. This initiative, proposed by more than 160 countries, aims to enhance the current system that relies on ground-based radars. The move was partly influenced by the 2014 disappearance of MH370, which highlighted the system's limitations, such as covering only 30% of the world's airspace. The new system will allow real-time tracking of aircraft worldwide, as stated by ITU's head. The UN's aviation body, ICAO, has set a deadline for adopting new tracking guidelines by November 2016.

Julian Hernandez, a 18-year-old boy, disappeared at age five and was found living with his father, Bobby Hernandez, in Cleveland. Bobby was arrested and charged with tampering with records in Ohio. The FBI, working with Alabama police, confirmed Julian's identity after issues with his college application. Julian's mother was informed of his recovery, and Bobby is currently detained at the Cuyahoga County Jail with a $250,000 bail.

Firefighters spent several days at a site in Duncan Street after a blaze on 2 March, which disrupted train services and caused travel delays. The Environment Agency suspended Recovered Fuels Shipping Limited from accepting waste due to the fire, despite the company being mostly compliant with fire safety laws. The firm, operated by Asset and Land Group, must appeal the decision by 7 August and remove all waste from the site. Concerns over potential impacts on residents, transport, and the environment led to joint visits by fire safety officers and the EA. The fire's cause is still unknown.

A Just Russia, a pro-Kremlin party, proposed two bills linked to the Ukraine crisis, particularly the strong separatist and pro-Russian sentiment in Ukraine's Crimea region. One bill suggests Russia could accept territories whose people wish to join Russia if a neighboring state disintegrates. The second bill aims to expedite Russian passport issuance for Ukrainians, with no state tax, no need for previous residence in Russia, or giving up Ukrainian citizenship. This is also seen as support for Russian-speaking Ukrainians amidst the 'brown threat'.

McLaren, a team with a history of 182 grand prix wins, 12 drivers' world championships, and eight constructors' titles, is currently experiencing a decline in performance. Despite having a car that is considered among the best, they are struggling with issues related to their Honda power unit. This decline began in 2013 and has led to their current position in the fourth row of the grid. However, team boss Dennis remains optimistic, believing that McLaren will break Mercedes' dominance and win the title again.

Tommy, aged 44 from Everton, was shot in the head and chest at Stanley Meat Market in Liverpool, dying in the hospital. Three men, aged 29 and 32, were arrested and remain in custody. Officers believe a silver VW polo left the scene and are searching for it. CCTV footage near the market has not yet been fully analyzed for potential leads.

The passage provides information on various ways to celebrate Christmas online and share spiritual messages. It mentions Everyday Church Online, which offers virtual services and recorded sermons in multiple languages, with the first Christmas theme being Star Wars. Another highlighted platform is Guardians of Ancora, a free-to-play fantasy game developed by the Scripture Union, aimed at children aged 8-11, which incorporates Bible stories into its gameplay. Additionally, the passage discusses the use of social media platforms like Facebook, Twitter, and Instagram for sharing Gospel messages and connecting with communities. It also touches on the use of Manga to convey biblical stories, with Next Manga launching its nativity story in app and e-book form in English.

The eight-day hearing in Ebbw Vale is assessing a request to develop 250 hectares of common land. Supporters, including Blaenau Gwent council, propose 800 acres of replacement land. Experts are divided on the potential environmental impact, with Natural Resources Wales unable to confirm the replacement land's equal value but not opposing the development. An ecology report suggests a "net gain" in biodiversity due to habitat enhancement nearby, a claim contested by the Gwent wildlife trust. The Planning Inspectorate for Wales will provide a recommendation before Welsh government ministers decide on the project's approval.

Chechen Muslim clerics, after a report by Novaya Gazeta, declared the publication insulted their faith and called for "retribution" against those responsible, including journalists. The report detailed the detention and torture of over 100 people in Chechnya, suspected of being homosexual. The Russian LGBT Network confirmed the report's accuracy, highlighting the region's homophobia. Novaya Gazeta's chief editor assured that their intent was not to insult the Chechen people and pledged to continue investigating human rights abuses. The Network also threatened to take the case to the International Criminal Court if Russia does not act against the abuses.

Investing Solutions and Fresh Start Housing, based in south London, have been involved in housing homeless men and passing rents to private landlords. The charity Fresh Start Housing sources clients from London homeless charities and refers them to both Investing Solutions and private landlords. Investing Solutions primarily receives housing benefit payments, which are higher than the rent paid to landlords. The company focuses on housing single homeless men over 35, despite housing benefit legislation allowing for private accommodation for this age group. Criticism has been raised regarding the quality of properties provided and the profitability of the venture. Wandsworth Council has paid Investing Solutions over £2.1 million in housing benefit over the past two years.

Andrew Lawrence and Ben Gordon, representing GB, scored a combined 27 points in a game where they initially led but were eventually overtaken by Netherlands in the last 10 minutes. Despite their efforts, GB lost to Netherlands, who won with a score of 71-60. The game was described as well-contested, and GB's coach, Joe Prunty, emphasized the importance of maintaining intensity throughout the game. Gordon, who joined GB after missing London 2012, had a notable performance, especially in the third quarter.

Former UFC champion Conor McGregor submitted a waiver to the Nevada Athletic Commission (NAC) to use lighter 8oz gloves for his boxing debut against Floyd Mayweather. This decision, which could result in more punishing punches, was met with criticism from boxing personalities. However, NAC executive director Bob Bennett, after studying information on McGregor and considering his UFC rival Nate Diaz's boxing skills, expressed several reasons to approve the fight. Despite some controversy, the NAC will publicly debate the matter before making a decision.

Reporters Gavin Sherriff and Darryl Smith, who worked for the Sunday Post, witnessed the closure of Fleet Street, a historic location in London known for its significant role in the nation's journalism. Fleet Street, synonymous with major newspapers, was once a hub for journalists, with offices of national and provincial papers within a half-mile radius. However, the rise of television and social media, along with the shift to computerized printing technology, led to the decline of Fleet Street's prominence. Media tycoon Rupert Murdoch's relocation of his papers in 1986 further contributed to the decline. The closure of Fleet Street marks the end of an era, with the last two journalists reflecting on the rich history and significance of the location.

J.K. Rowling, the author of Harry Potter, faced abusive comments on Twitter due to her political donations. She donated £1m to the Labour party in 2008 and to the No campaign in the Scottish independence referendum in 2014. Critics called her a traitor for her political views, leading her to block some abusive users. Despite the negativity, Rowling stood up to bullies and maintained her stance, even joking about bringing marshmallows if her books were to be burned. The SNP won 56 seats in the recent election, making them the third largest party in the UK.

The passage discusses a study by the University of Edinburgh, which found that children from deprived backgrounds are twice as likely to face police action for the same crime as better-off children. Poverty also increases the likelihood of violence among both genders. The study found that a history of police trouble predicts a young person's lack of education, employment, or training by age 18. Poorer young people are more likely to be placed on statutory supervision and are more likely to be victims and perpetrators of crime, even when other risk factors are considered. The study also found that areas with the most chronic rates of crime continue to experience high crime rates, and that these areas often have high levels of chronic health problems and unemployment. Despite overall crime rates in Scotland being at a 41-year low, the study suggests that crime is still highly concentrated among poor people and in poor neighborhoods. The Scottish government has initiatives in place to tackle poverty and inequalities.

Robbie Walsh, 25, was charged with assault causing serious harm to Mr. Haugh, who was stabbed and died in a fight involving three men in Kilkee. Two other arrested men were released without charge. Walsh was remanded in custody until August 14, with evidence of local tension following the incident.

Phil Flanagan, an MLA, tweeted a false accusation against Tom Elliott, a former UDR member and current MP, in May 2014. The tweet, which was deleted within an hour, implied that Elliott harassed and shot people during his service. Elliott, who has a clear MoD record, was alerted to the tweet by victims' campaigner Ann Travers and DUP assembly member Arlene Foster. Flanagan later apologized, admitting the tweet was untrue. The insurance firm covering MLAs refused to cover Flanagan for any compensation, leading to a separate court action. Despite the ordeal, Elliott expressed satisfaction with the outcome.

Hawick Knitwear, employing over 230 staff, increased its sweater production from 7,500 to 9,500 weekly due to high demand for its brand and private label clients. The company, founded in 1874, was acquired by Benny Hartop last year. Hawick Knitwear sells in Europe and internationally, including the USA, Canada, Mexico, and Japan. Mr. Hartop anticipates continued success due to dedicated staff and growing demand.

Sylvia Blackburn, 72, suffered serious head injuries after being hit by Brian Wright, 55, who claimed he was blinded by the sun. Wright, a lollipop lady for 20 years, admitted hitting Blackburn but denied causing serious injury through dangerous driving. The incident occurred when Blackburn stepped out to guide a woman and her daughter across the road during sunset. Wright could not recall if the traffic lights were red or green, and the sun was shining directly into his eyes. The trial is ongoing.

The passage discusses a Nato exercise named "Dynamic Mongoose" in response to the growing threat from Russian submarines. The exercise involves 10 Nato warships, including a Royal Navy Frigate, and anti-submarine warfare helicopters. The German U-boat U33, commanded by Kai Nicklesdorf, is trying to avoid detection while attempting to take out the command ship, the USS Vicksburg, and an oil tanker. The exercise highlights a gap in Britain's defences, as it no longer has any maritime patrol aircraft. The underwater unmanned vehicles or drones, named Harpo and Groucho, are also mentioned as aiding in the search. The purpose of the exercise is to ensure Nato is ready to conduct anti-submarine warfare, but it also underscores the need for nations like Britain to address their deficiencies.

United Nations officials are concerned about potential genocide and ethnic cleansing in South Sudan, the world's youngest country. Since July, violence in Juba and southern Equatoria states forced over 340,000 people to flee into neighboring Uganda, more than any other country this year. The UN reports that 2,500 South Sudanese become refugees daily. The violence, marked by killings, rape, and targeting of civilians along ethnic lines, has led to a massive influx of refugees into Uganda. Despite Uganda's generous response, supplying water to the refugees has become a problem. The international community is urged to pressure South Sudanese leaders to stop the violence.

McKenzie, 38, aims to win the English super-middleweight championship against Jahmaine Smyle on 12th November at York Hall. A former footballer who turned professional boxer in 2013, McKenzie has eight wins and one draw in nine fights. He is the son of Clinton, a former British and European champion, and trained by his uncle Duke, a three-time world champion.

Bridgwater Community Hospital is set to receive funding as part of a £330m investment for new NHS facilities in England. The new hospital will feature 30 inpatient beds, a midwifery-led maternity unit, a minor injury unit, and space for X-ray and mobile scanners. The current hospital, built in 1813, is outdated and cramped. The project cost is £33m, with the balance covered by NHS Somerset and Somerset Partnership NHS Foundation Trust. The new hospital aims to improve patient recovery and well-being, with construction planned to finish by autumn 2014.

A man was fatally shot outside a property on Daniel Hill Terrace, Upperthorpe, near Sheffield city centre. The victim, a family member, was either in or near a black Mercedes car he was driving when shot. This incident occurred during a family gathering, and the man was taken to the hospital but died from his injuries. This shooting is among several recent ones in Sheffield, but the others were in the city's northern areas.

The passage discusses the activities of three cyber groups involved in the conflict between Ukraine and Russia. The Ukrainian Cyber Troops, led by Yevhen Dokukin, are known for hacking into Russian servers and using DDoS attacks to disrupt rebel websites and electronic payment systems. Dokukin has also claimed to have hijacked CCTV systems and network printers to spread pro-Ukrainian messages. On the other side, Cyber Berkut, an anti-Western group, has targeted Ukrainian government websites, electronic billboards, and reportedly disrupted electronic vote-counting systems. They have also published confidential documents and messages suggesting Ukrainian involvement in the downing of Malaysia Airlines flight MH17. Lastly, Anonymous International, a group focused on Russia's domestic affairs, has published leaked documents and emails, some of which pertain to Ukraine. Their methods of obtaining information are unclear.

Tricia Marwick, Duncan McNeil, and Mr. Salmond are among the MSPs stepping down before the 5 May election. Mr. Salmond, former first minister, delivered a valedictory address emphasizing Scotland's diversity and unity, the need for the parliament to take greater responsibility, and the transfer of powers under the Scotland Bill. He also joked about competition from the UK budget and wished success to his political rivals. Duncan McNeil, a Scottish Labour backbencher, warned Holyrood to learn from Westminster's committee system and stressed the importance of accountability and scrutiny. Annabel Goldie, a former Scottish Conservative MSP, humorously mentioned her interactions with Finance Secretary John Swinney in her farewell speech.

Sarah Rochira, Older People's Commissioner for Wales, is conducting a review into the quality of life and care of older people in residential care. She plans to gather experiences from pensioners, their families, and care providers to develop recommendations. The review will consider factors like physical and psychological health, social relationships, and the care home environment. While the commissioner aims to highlight good care and address poor care, the care sector expressed disappointment over the lack of a care provider expert on the main advisory panel.

Harbro Group, based in Aberdeenshire, reported a pre-tax profit increase of £800,000 to £3.5m for the year ending June 2016. Despite a £1m decrease in turnover, international sales grew. Harbro manufactures feeds for various livestock sectors and operates 19 Country Store shops in Scotland, offering products for farming and rural communities. The company acknowledges challenging times in agriculture, partly due to Brexit, but remains optimistic about its future position.

A man in his 70s was found dead at a house in Nettleden Road, Little Gaddesden, near Berkhamsted, and a man in his 80s was hospitalized. The police are investigating the death as murder and want to question 55-year-old Ian John McLoughlin, known as Ian John Baker. Detectives urge people not to approach him and have advised residents to report any information. Ian is described as white, around 6ft tall, with greying hair, and believed to have been wearing sunglasses, blue jeans or three-quarter length trousers, and a specific shirt.

David Lipton, the IMF's second-in-command, warned of a weakening global economy at a delicate juncture, citing downgraded growth forecasts and China's declining exports. This situation impacts businesses and industries relying on China's growth.

The council leader announced that the Cowes crossing would be free until 2 July due to issues with a new chain ferry, which has experienced breakdowns, run aground, and caused vehicle damage.
